titleStmt.title: Jonson, Ben, 1573?-1637 : : A tale of a tub (1640)

editionStmt.p: This electronic version was produced at the Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing at the University of Newcastle by keyboarding from a microfilm printout of an early printed version. It was originally in a format devised in the Centre, with reference panels at the beginning of each line, known as "LILAC". It was subsequently converted by an automated process to a TEI XML format. It lacks the speaker tags provided in the copytext. Contractions and variant spellings of function words have been silently regularised. The text thus lacks information about the original forms of many words and expressions.

publicationStmt.publisher: Ben Jonson, 1573?-1637 (1572?-1637) A tale of a tub [in, The workes of Benjamin Jonson] London Printed for Richard Meighen 1640

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
A tale of a tub. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1640. Date first performed: 1595-1598.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Sir Hugh Squire Tub Basket Hilts Justice Preamble/Bramble Miles Metaphor Lady Tub Pol-Marten Dido Wispe Tobie Turfe Sibil Turfe Mrs Audrey Turfe John Clay Medlay Rasi Clench To Pan D'oge Scriben Ball Puppy Prologue Joan Joyce, maid Kate, maid Black Jack 1 Groom 2 Groom combined voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.l: No State-affairs, nor any politic Club,
Pretend we in our Tale, here, of a Tub.
But acts of Clowns and Constables, today
Stuff out the Scenes of our ridiculous Play.
A Coopers wit, or some such busy Spark,
Illumining the high Constable, and his Clarke.
And all the Neighbour-hood, from old Records,
Of antic Proverbs, drawn from Whitson-Lord's,
And their Authorities, at Wakes and Ales,
With country precedents, and old Wives Tales;
We bring you now, to show what different things
The Cotes of Clowns, are from the Courts of Kings.
Now on my faith, old Bishop Valentine,
You have brought us nipping weather: February
Doth cut and shear; your day, and diocese
Are very cold. All your parishioners;
As well as your Laics, as your Choristers,
Had need to keep to their warm Father-beds,
If they be sped of loves: this is no season,
To seek new Makes in; though Sir Hugh of Pancrace,
Be hither come to Totten, on intelligence,
To the young Lord of the Manor, Squire Tripoly,
On such an errand as a Mistress is.
What, Squire! I say? Tub. I should call him too:
Sir Peter Tub was his father, a Salt-petre-man;
Who left his Mother, Lady Tub of Totten-Court,
here, to revel, and keep open house in;
With the young Squire her son, and his Governor Basket
Hilts,
both by sword, and dagger: Domine,
Armiger Tub, Squire Tripoly, Expergiscere.
I dare not call aloud, lest she should hear me;
And think I conjured up the spirither, son,
In Priests-Iack-latine: O she is jealous
Of all man-kind for him.
Canon, is it you?
The Vicar of Pancrace, Squire Tub! wa'hoh!

stage.l: He comes down in his night Gown.

sp.l: I come, I stoop unto the call; Sir Hugh!
He knows my lure is from his Love: fair Awdrey,
The high Constables Daughter of Kentish Town, here Mr.
Tobias Turfe.
What news of him?
He has waked me,
An hour before I would, Sir. And my duty,
To the young worship of Totten-Court, Squire Tripoly;
Who hath my heart, as I have his: your Mrs.
Is to be made away from you, this morning,
Saint Valentines day: there are a knot of Clowns,
The Counsel of Finsbury, so they are styled,
Met at her Fathers; all the wise of the hundred;
Old Basi' Clench of Hamsted, petty Constable;
In-and-in Medlay, Cooper of Islington,
And Headborough; with loud To-Pan the Tinker,
Or Metal-man of Belsise, the Third-borough:
And Diogenes Scriben, the great Writer of Chalcot.
And why all these?
Sir to conclude in Counsel,
A Husband, or a Make for Mrs. Awdrey;
Whom they have named, and pricked down,
Clay of Kilborne,
A tough young fellow, and a Tile-maker.
And what must he do?
Cover her, they say:
And keep her warm Sir: Mrs. Awdrey Turfe,
Last night did draw him for her Valentine;
Which chance, it hath so taken her Father, and
Mother,
(Because themselves drew so, on Valentine's Eve
Was thirty year) as they will have her married
Today by any means; they have sent a Messenger
To Kilborne, post, for Clay; which when I knew,
I posted with the like to worshipful Tripoly,
The Squire of Totten: and my advise to cross it.
What is it Sir Hugh?
Where is your Governor Hilts?
Basquet must do it.
Basquet shall be called:
Hilts, can you see to rise?
I am not blind Sir
With too much light.
Open your the other eye,
And view if it be day.
I can spy that
At as little a hole, as another, through a Millstone.
He will have the last word, though he talk Bilk for it.
Bilk? what is that?
Why nothing, a word signifying
Nothing; and borrowed here to express nothing.
A fine device!
Yes till we hear a finer.
What is your device now, Canon Hugh?
In private.
Lend it your ear; I will not trust the air with it;
Or scarce my Shirt; my Cassock shall not know it;
If I thought it did, I will burn it.
That is the way,
You have thought to get a new one,
Is it worth it?
Let us hear it first.

stage.l: They whisper. Hilts enters, and walks by,

sp.l: Then hearken, and receive it.
This it is Sir, do you relish it?
If Hilts
Be close enough to carry it; there is all.
It is no sand? nor Buttermilk? If it be,
I am no sieve or watering pot, to draw
Knots in your occasions. If you trust me so:
If not, perform it yourselves. I am no man's wife,
but resolute Hilts: you will find me in the Buttery.
A testy Clown: but a tender Clown, as wool:
And melting as the Weather in a Thaw:
He will weep you, like all April: But he will roar
you
Like middle March before: He
will be as mellow,
And tipsy too, as October: And as grave,
And bound up like a frost (with the new year)
In January; as rigid, as he is rustic.
You know his nature, and describe it well;
I will leave him to your fashioning.
Stay, Sir Hugh;
Take a good Angel with you, for your Guide:
And let this guard you home-ward, as the blessing,
To our devise.
I thank you Squires-worship,
Most humbly
(for the next, for this I am sure of.)
O for a Quire of those voices, now,
To chime in a man's pocket, and cry chink!
One doth not chirp: it makes no harmony.
Grave Justice Bramble, next must contribute;
His charity must offer at this wedding:
I will bid more to the Basin, and the Bride-ale;
Although but one can bear away the Bride.
I smile to think how like a Lottery
These Weddings are. Clay hath her in possession,
The Squire he hopes to circumvent the Tile-Kill:
And now, if Justice Bramble do come off,
It is two to one but Tub may loose his bottom.
Why, it is thirty year, even as this day now:
Zin Valentines day, of all days cursin'd, look you;
And the same day of the month, as this Zin Valentine,
Or I am foully deceived.
That our High Constable,
Mr. Tobias Turfe, and his Dame were married.
I think you are right. But what was that Zin Valentine?
Did you ever know them, Good-man Clench?
Zin Valentine,
He was a deadly Zin, and dwelt at High-gate,
As I have heard, but it was afore my time:
He was a Cooper too, as you are. Medlay,
And In-an-In: A woundy, brag young fellow:
As the port went of him, then, and in those days.
Did he not write his name, Sim Valentine?
For I have met no Sin in Finsbury books;
And yet I have writ them six or seven times over.
O you must look for the nine deadly Sims,
In the Church books, Doge; not the high Constables;
Nor in the Counties: Sure, that same Zin Valentine,
He was a stately Zin: and he were a Zin,
And kept brave house.
At the Cock and Hen, in High-gate,
You have refreshed my memory well in it! neighbour Pan:
He had a place, in last King Harrie's time,
Of sorting all the young couples; joining them;
And putting them together; which is, yet,
Performed, as on his day -- Zin Valentine;
As being the Zin of the shire, or the whole County:
I am old Rivet still, and bear a brain,
The Clench, the Farrier, and true Leach of Hamsted.
You are a shrewd antiquity, neighbour Clench!
And a great Guide to all the Parishes!
The very Bellwether of the Hundred, here,
As I may say. Mr. Tobias Turfe,
High Constable, would not miss you, for a score of us,
When he do scorse of the great Charity to us.
What is that, a Horse? Can scorse nought but a Horse?.
I near read of him, and that in Smith-veld Charity:
In the old Fabian's Chronicles: nor I think
In any new. He may be a Giant there,
For Aye aught I know.
You should do well to study
Records, Fellow Ball, both Law and Poetry.
Why, all is but writing, and reading, is it Scriben?
If it be any more, it is a mere cheating sure.
Flat cheating: all your Law, and Poets too.
Mr. High Constable comes.
I will say it afore him.

stage.l: Turfe. Clench. Medlay. Scriben. Puppy. Pan.

sp.l: What is that, makes you all so merry, and loud, Sirs,
ha?
I could have heard you to my privy walk.
A Controversies, betwixt your two learned men here:
Annibal Puppy says, that Law and Poetry
Are both flat cheating; All is but writing and reading,
He says, be it verse or prose.
I think in conscience,
He do say true? Who is it do thwart him, ha?
Why my friend Scriben, if it please your worship.
Who D'oge? my Diogenes? a great Writer, marry!
He will face me down, me myself
sometimes,
That verse goes upon feet, as you and I do:
But I can give him the hearing; zit me down ,
And laugh at him; and to myself
conclude,
The greatest Clerks, are not the wisest men
Ever. Here they are both! What Sirs, disputing,
And holding Arguments of verse, and prose?
And no green thing before the
Door, that shows,
Or speaks a wedding?
Those were verses now,
Your worship spake, and run upon five feet.
Feet, from my mouth, D'oge? Leave your absurd opinions:
And get me in some boughs.
Let them have leaves first.
There is nothing green but Bays, and Rosemary.
And they are too good for strewings, your Maids say.
You take up 'dority still, to vouch against me.
All the twelve smocks in the house, sir, are your Authors.
Get some fresh hay then, to lay underfoot:
Some Holly and Ivy, to make vine the posts:
Is it not Son Valentines day? and Mrs. Awdrey,
Your young Dame to be married? I wonder Clay
Should be so tedious; He is to play Son Valentine!
And the Clown sluggard is not come from Kilborne yet?
Do you call your Son-in-Law Clown, if it please your worship?
Yes, and for worship too; my neighbour Medlay.
A Midlesex Clown, and one of Finsbury:
They were the first Colon's of the kingdom here:
The Primitory Colon's, my Diogenes says.
Where is Diogenes, my Writer now? What were those
You told me, Diogenes, were the first Colon's
Of the Country? that the Romans brought in here?
The Colony. Sir, Colonus is an Inhabitant:
A Clown original: as you would say a Farmer, a Tiller of the
Earth,
Ever since the
Romans planted their Colony first,
Which was in Midlesex.
Why so, I thank you heartily, good Diogenes, you have
certified me.
I had rather be an ancient Colon, (as they say) a Clown of
Midlesex:
A good rich Farmer, or high Constable.
I would play hun gain a Knight, or a good Squire;
Or Gentleman of any other County
In the Kingdom.
Out-cept Kent, for there they landed
All Gentlemen, and came in with the Conqueror,
Mad Iulius Cæsar; who built Dover-Castle:
My Ancestor To-Pan, beat the first Kettledrum,
Afore him, here from Dover on the March:
Which piece of monumental copper hangs
Up, scoured, at Hammer-smith yet; for there they came
Over the Thames, at a low water mark;
For either London, aye, or Kingston Bridge --
I doubt were christened.
See, who is here: Iohn Clay?
Son Valentine, and Bridegroom! have you seen
Your Valentine-Bride yet, since you
came? Iohn Clay!
No wuss. I lighted, I, but now in the yard:
Puppy have scarce unswaddled my legs yet.
What? wisps on your wedding day, son? This is right
Originous Clay: And Clay of Kilborne too!
I would have had boots of this day, sure, son Iohn.
I did it to save charges: we must dance,
On this day, sure: and who can dance in boots?
No, I got on my best straw-coloured stockings
and swaddled them over to save charges; I.
And his new chamois Doublet too with points;
I like that yet: and his long sausage-hose,
Like the Commander of four smoking Tile-kils,
Which he is Captain of; Captain of Kilborne:
Clay with his hat turned up, on the leer side, too:
As if he would leap my Daughter yet ere night,
And spring a new Turfe to the old house:
Look, if the wenches have not found him out;
And do present him, with a van of Rosemary,
And Bays; to fill a Bow-pot; trim the head
Of my best fore-horse: we shall all have Bride-laces,
Or points, I see; my Daughter will be valiant;
And prove a very Mary Anbry in the business.
They said, your worship had sur'd her to Squire Tub
Of Totten-Court here; all the hundred rings on it.
A Tale of a Tub, Sir; a mere tale of a Tub.
Lend it no ear I pray you: The Squire Tub
Is a fine man, but he is too fine a man,
And has a Lady Tub too to his Mother:
I will deal with none of these vine silken Tubs.
Iohn Clay, and Cloath-breech for my money, and Daughter.
Here comes another old Boy too, for his colours
Will stroke down my wives udder
of purses, empty
Of all her milk money, this Winter Quarter;
Old Father Rosin, the chief Minstrel here:
Chief Minstrel too of High gate: she has hired him
And all, his two Boys for a day and a half,
And now they come for Ribbanding, and Rosemary;
Give them enough Girls, give them enough, and take it
Out in his tunes anon.
I will have Tom Tiler,
For our Iohn Clay's sake, and the Tile kills, sure.
And I the jolly Joiner, for mine own
sake.
I will have the jovial Tinker for To Pans sake.
We will all be jovy this day, for son Valentine.
My sweet son Iohn's sake.
There is another reading now:
My Mr. reads it Son, and not Sin Valentine.
Nor Zim: And he is in the right: He is high Constable.
And who should read above him, or afore him?
Son Iohn shall bid us welcome all, this day:
We will serve under his colours: Lead the troop Iohn,
And Puppy; see the Bells ring. Press all noises
Of Finsbury, in our name; Diogenes Scriben
Shall draw a score of warrants for the business.
Does any wight present his Majesties person,
This Hundred, above the high
Constable?
No, no.
Use our Authority then, to the utmost of it.
So, you are sure Sir to prevent them all;
And throw a block in the Bridegrooms way, Iohn Clay,
That he will hardly leap over.
I conceive you,
Sir Hugh; as if your Rhetoric would say,
Whereas the Father of her is a Turfe,
A very superficies of the earth;
He aims no higher, than to match in Clay;
And there hath pitched his rest.
Right Justice Bramble;
You have the winding wit, compassing all.
Subtle Sir Hugh, you now are in the wrong,
And err with the whole Neighbour-hood, I must tell you;
For you mistake myself; which with
the ignorant Clowns, here
(Because of my profession of the Law,
And place of the peace is taken to be Bramble.
But all my warrants Sir, do run Preamble:
Richard Preamble.
Sir I thank you for it.
That your good worship, would not let me run
Longer in error, but would take me up thus --
You are my learned, and canonical neighbour:
I would not have you stray; but the incorrigible
Knot-headed beast, the Clowns, or Constables,
Still let them graze; eat Salads; chew the Cud:
All the Town-music will not move a log.
The Beetle and Wedges will, where you will have them.
True, true Sir Hugh, here comes Miles Metaphore,
My Clarke: He is the man shall carry it, Canon,
By my instructions.
He will do it ad unguem,
Miles Metaphore: He is a pretty fellow.
I love not to keep shadows, or half-wits,
To foil a business. Metaphore! you have seen
A King ride forth in state.
Sir that I have:
King Edward our late Liege, and sovereign Lord:
And have set down the pomp.
Therefore I asked you.
Have you observed the Messengers of the Chamber?
What habits they were in?
Yes; Minor Coats.
Unto the Guard, a Dragon, and a Grey-hound,
For the supporters of the Arms.
Well marked;
You know not any of them?
Here is one dwells
In Maribone.
Have you acquaintance with him?
To borrow his coat an hour?
Or but his badge,
It will serve: A little thing he wares on his breast.
His coat, I say, is of more authority:
Borrow his coat for an hour. I do love
To do all things completely, Canon Hugh;
Borrow his coat, Miles Metaphore, or nothing.
The Taberd of his office, I will call it,
Or the Coat-Armour of his place: and so
Insinuate with him by that Trope --.
I know your powers of Rhetoric, Metaphore.
Fetch him off in a fine figure of his coat I say.
I will take my leave Sir of your worship too:
Because I may expect the issue
anon.
Stay my diviner Counsel, take your fee;
We that take fees, allow them to our
Counsel;
And our prime learned Counsel, double fees:
There are a brace of Angels to support you
In your foot-walk this frost, for fear of falling;
Or spraying of a point of Matrimony,
When you come at it.
In your worships service;
That the exploit is done, and you possessed
Of Mrs. Awdrey Turfe --
I like your project.
And I, of this effect of two to one;
It worketh in my pocket, against
the Squire,
And his half bottom here, of half, a piece: over
the style for:
His Mother has quite marred him: Lady Tub,
She is such a vessel of faeces: all dried earth!
Terra damnata, not a drop of salt!
Or Petre in her! all her Nitre is gone.
Is the Nag ready Marten? call the Squire.
This frosty morning we will take the air,
About the fields: for I do mean to be
Somebody's Valentine, in my
Velvet Gown,
This morning, though it be but a beggar-man.
Why stand you still, and do not call my son?
Madam, if he had couched with the Lamb,
He had no doubt been stirring with the Lark:
But he sat up at Play, and watched the Cock,
Till his first warning chid him off to rest.
Late Watchers are no early Wakers, Madam;
But if your Ladyship will have him called --.
Will have him called? Wherefore did I, Sir, bid him
Be called, you Weasel, Vermin of an Usher?
You will return your wit to your first style
Of Marten Polecat, by these stinking tricks,
If you do use them: I shall no more call you
Pol-marten, by the title of a Gentleman,
If you go on thus --
I am gone.
Be quick then,
In your come off: and make amends you Stote!
Was ever such a Full-mart for an Usher,
To a great worshipful Lady, as
myself;
Who, when I heard his name first, Martin Polecat,
A stinking name, and not to be pronounced
In any Ladies presence; my very heart even earned, seeing
the Fellow
Young, pretty and handsome; being then I say,
A Basket-Carrier, and a man condemned
To the Saltpetre works; made it my suit
To Mr. Peeter Tub, that I might change it;
And call him as I do now, by Pol-marten,
To have it sound like a Gentleman in an Office,
And made him mine own Fore-man, daily
waiter,
And he to serve me thus! Ingratitude!
Beyond the Coarseness yet of any Clownage.
Shown to a Lady! what now, is he stirring?
Stirring betimes out of his bed, and ready.
And comes he then?
No, Madam, he is gone.
Gone? whither? ask the Porter: Where is he gone?
I met the Porter, and have asked him for him;
He says he let him forth an hour ago.
And hour ago! what business could he have,
So early? where is his man, grave Basket-Hilts?
His Guide, and Governor?
Gone with his Master.
Is he gone too? O that same surly knave,
Is his right hand: and leads my son amiss.
He has carried him to some drinking match, or other:
Pol-marten, I will call you so
again;
I am friends with you now. Go get your horse, and ride
To all the Towns about here, where his haunts are;
And cross the fields to meet, and bring me word;
He cannot be gone far, being afoot.
Be curious to inquire him: and bid Wisp
My woman come, and wait on me. The love
We Mothers bear our Sons, we have bought with
pain,
Makes us oft view them, with too careful eyes,
And overlook them with a jealous fear,
Out-fitting Mothers.
How now Wisp? Have you
A Valentine yet: I am taking the air to choose one.
Fate send your Ladyship a fit one then.
What kind of one is that?
A proper man,
To please your Ladyship.
Out on that vanity,
That takes the foolish eye: Any poor creature,
Whose want may need my alms, or courtesy;
I rather wish, so Bishop Valentine,
Left us example to do deeds of Charity;
To feed the hungry; cloth the naked, visit
The weak, and sick; to entertain the poor;
And give the dead a Christian Funeral;
These were the works of piety he did practise,
And bad us imitate; not look for Lovers,
Or handsome Images to please our senses.
I Pray thee Wisp, deal freely with me now:
We are alone, and may be merry a little:
Thou art none of the Court-glories; nor the wonders
For wit, or beauty in the City: tell me,
What man would satisfy thy present fancy?
Had thy ambition leave to choose a Valentine,
Within the Queens Dominion, so a subject.
You have give me a large scope, Madam, I confess,
And I will deal with your Ladyship sincerely:
I will utter my whole heart to you. I would have him,
The bravest, richest, and the properest man
A Taylor could make up; or all the Poets,
With the Perfumers: I would have him such;
As not another woman, but should spite me:
Three City Ladies should run mad for him:
And country madams infinite.
You would spare me,
And let me hold my wits?
I should with you --
For the young Squire, my Masters sake: dispense
A little; but it should be very little.
Then all the Court-wives I would have jealous of me;
As all their husbands jealous of them:
And not a Lawyers Puss of any quality,
But lick her lips, for a snatch in the Term time.
Come,
Let us walk: we will hear the rest, as we
go on:
You are this morning in a good veine, Dido:
Would I could be as merry. My sons absence
Troubles me not a little: though I seek
These ways to put it off, which will not help:
Care that is entered, once into the breast,
Will have the whole possession, ere it rest.

stage.l: Turfe. Clay. Medlay. Clench. To-Pan. Scriben. Puppy.

sp.l: Son Clay, cheer up, the better leg afore:
This is a feast is once done, and no more.
And then it is done for ever, as they say.
Right! for a man have his hour, and a dog his day.
True neighbour Medlay, you are still In-and-In.
I would be Mr. Constable, if I could win.
I say, Iohn Clay, keep still on his old gate:
Wedding, and hanging, both go at a rate.
Well said To-Pan: you have still the hap to hit
The nail on the head at a close: I think there never
Marriage was managed with a more advisement,
Then was this marriage, though I say it, that should not;
Especially against mine
own flesh, and blood;
My wedded Wife. Indeed my Wife would have had
All the young Bachelors and Maids, forsooth,
Of the six Parishes hereabout: But I
Cried none, sweet Sybil: none of that gear, I:
It would lick salt, I told her, by her leave.
No, three, or four our wise, choice honest neighbours:
Substantial persons: men that have borne office:
And mine own Family, would be
To eat our dinner. What? Dear meat is a thief:
I know it by the Butchers, and the Market-folks;
Hum drum I cry. No half-Ox in a Pie:
A man that is bid to Bride-ale, if he have cake,
And drink enough, he need not fear his stake.
It is right: he has spoke as true as a Gun; believe it.
Come Sybil, come: Did not I tell you of this?
This pride, and muster of women would mar all?
Six women to one Daughter, and a Mother!
The Queen (God save her) have no more
Why, if you keep so many, Mr. Turfe,
Why, should not all present our service to her?
Your service? good! I think you will write to her
shortly,
Your very loving and obedient Mother.
Come, send your Maids off, I will have them sent
Home again wife: I love no
trains of Kent,
Or Christendom, as they say.
We will not back,
And leave our Dame.
Why should her worship lack
Her tail of Maids, more than you do of men?
What, mutinin Madge?
Send back your C'lons again.
And we will follow.
Else we will guard our Dame.
I have set the nest of wasps all on a flame.
Come, you are such another Mr. Turfe:
A clod you should be called, of a high Constable:
To let no music go before
your Child,
To Church, to cheer her heart up this cold
morning.
You are for Father Rosin, and his consort
Of fiddling Boys, the great Feats, and the less:
Because you have entertained them
all from High-gate.
To show your pomp, you would have your Daughter, and Maids
Dance over the fields like Fays,
to Church this frost?
I will have no rondels, I, in the Queens paths;
Let them scrape the Gut at home, where they have filled it
At afternoon.
I will have them play at dinner.
She is in the right, Sir; for your wedding dinner
Is starved without the Music.
If the Pies
Come not in piping hot, you have lost that Proverb.
I yield to truth: wife are you satisfied?
A right good man! when he knows right, he loves it.
And he will know it, and show it too by his place
Of being high Constable, if nowhere else.
Well over-taken, Gentlemen! I pray you,
Which is the Queens High Constable among you?
The tallest man: who should be else, do you think?
It is no matter what I think, young Clown:
Your answer favours of the Cart.
How? Cart?
And Clown? Do you know whose team you speak to?
No: nor I care not: Whose Jade may you be?
Jade? Cart? and Clown? O for a lash of whip-cord!
Three-knotted cord!
Do you mutter? Sir, snarl this way;
That I may hear, and answer what you say,
With my school-dagger, about your
Costard Sir.
Look to it, young grouse: I will lay it on, and
sure;
Take it off who will.
Nay, pray you Gentleman --
Go to: I will not bate him an ace of it.
What? Rowle-powle? Maple-face? All fellows?
Do you hear friend, I would wish you, for your good,
Tie up your branded Bitch there, your dun rusty
Pannier-hilt poniard: and not vex the youth
With showing the teeth of it. We now are going
To church, in way of matrimony, some of us:
They have rung all in already.
If it had not,
All the horn beasts are grazing in this close,
Should not have pull me hence, till this Ash-plant
Had rung noon on your pate, Mr. Broome-beard.
That would I fain see, quoth the blind George
Of Holloway: Come Sir.
O their naked weapons!
For the passion of man, hold Gentleman, and Puppy.
Murder, O Murder!
O my Father, and Mother!
Husband, what do you mean? Son Clay for Gods sake --
I charge you in the Queens name, keep the peace.
Tell me of no Queen, or Kaiser: I must have
A leg, or a haunch of him, ere I go.
But sir,
You must obey the Queens high Officers.
Why must I, Good-man Must?
You must, and you will.
Gentleman, I am here for fault, high Constable --
Are you so? what then?
I pray you Sir put up
Your weapons; do, at my request: For him,
On my authority, he shall lie by the heels,
Verbatim continente, if I live.
Out on him for a knave, what a dead fright
He has put me into? Come Awdrey, do not shake.
But is not Puppy hurt? nor the the other man?
No Bun; but had not I cried Murder, I wuss --
Sweet Good-man Clench, I pray you revise my Mr.
I may not zit in the stocks, till the wedding be past
Dame. Mrs. Awdrey: I shall break the Bride-cake else.
Something must be, to save authority, Puppy.
Husband --
And Gossip --
Father --
Treat
me not.
It is in vain. If he lie not by the heels,
I will lie there for him. I will teach the Hine,
To carry a tongue in his head, to his superiors.
This is a wise Constable! where keeps he school?
In Kentish Town, a very severe men.
But as severe as he is; Let me Sir tell him,
He shall not lay his man by the ears for this.
This was my quarrel: And by his office leave,
If it carry him for this, it shall carry double;
For he shall carry me too.
Breath of man!
He is my chattel, mine own hired
goods:
If if you do abet him in this matter,
I will clap you both by the heels, ankle to ankle.
You will clap a dog of wax as soon, old Blurt?
Come, spare not me, Sir; I am no man's wife:
I care not, I, Sir, not three skips of a Louse for you,
And you were ten tall Constables, not I.
Nay, pray you Sir, be not angry; but content:
My man shall make you, what amends you will ask him.
Let him mend his manners then, and know his betters:
It is all I ask him: and it will be his
own;
And his Masters too, another day. I for him.
As right as a Club, still. Sure this angry man
Speaks very near the mark, when he is pleased.
I thank you Sir, if I meet you at Kentish Town,
I have the curtsy of hundred for you.
Gramercy, good high Constables Hine. But hear you:
Mass: Constable, I have other manner of matter,
To bring you about, than this. And so it is,
I do belong to one of the Queens Captains;
A Gentleman of the Field, one Captain Thum's:
I know not, whether you know him, or no: It may be
You do, and it may be you do not again.
No, I assure you on my Constable-ship,
I do not know him.
Nor I neither in faith.
It skills not much, my Captain, and
myself,
Having occasion to come riding by, here,
This morning, at the corner of Saint Iohn's wood,
Some mile of this Town, were set upon
By a sort of country fellows: that not
Beat us, but robbed us, most sufficiently;
And bound us to our behaviour, hand and foot;
And so they left us. Now, Don Constable,
I am to charge you in her Majesties name,
As you will answer it at your peril,
That forthwith you raise Hue and Cry in the Hundred,
For all such persons as you can suspect,
By the length and breadth, on your office: for I tell
you,
The loss is of some value, therefore look to it.
As Fortune mend me, now, or any office
Of a thousand pound, if I know what to say,
Would I were dead; or fair hanged up at Tiburne,
If I do know what course to take; or how
To turn myself; just at this
time too, now,
My Daughter is to be married: I will but go
To Pancridge Church, hard by, and return instantly,
And all my Neighbour-hood shall go about it.
Tut, Pancridge me no Pancridge, if you let it
Slip, you will answer it, if your Cap be of wool;
Therefore take heed, you will feel the smart else,
Constable.
Nay, good Sir stay. Neighbours! what think you of this?
Faith, Man --. Odd precious woman, hold your tongue;
And mind your pigs on the spit at home, you must
Have Ore in everything.
Pray you Sir, what kind
Of fellows were they?
Thieves kind, I have told you.
I mean, what kind of men?
Men of our make.
Nay, but with patience, Sir, we that are Officers
Must enquire the special marks, and all the tokens
Of the despected parties, or perhaps -- else,
Be never the near of our purpose
in apprehending them.
Can you tell, what apparel any of them wore?
Troth no: there were so many of them, all like
So one another: Now I remember me,
There was one busy fellow, was their Leader;
A blunt squat swad, but lower than yourself,
He had on a Leather Doublet, with long points.
And a pair of pinned-up breech's, like pudding bags:
With yellow stockings, and his hat turned up
With a silver Clasp, on his leer side.
By these
Marks it should be Iohn Clay, now bless the man!
Peace and be nought: I think the woman be frantic.
Iohn Clay? what is he, good Mistress?
He that shall be
My husband --
How! your husband, pretty one?
Yes, I shall anon be married: That is he.
Passion of me, undone!
Bless Masters son!
O you are well apprehended: know you me Sir?
No is my record: I never saw you afore.
You did not? where were your eyes then? out at washing?
What should a man say? who should he trust
In these days? Hark you Iohn Clay, if you have
Done any such thing, tell troth, and shame the Devil.
Faith do: my Gossip Turfe says well to you Iohn.
Speak man, but do not confess, nor be afraid.
A man is a man, and a beast is a beast, look to it.
In the name of men, or beasts! what do you do?
Hare the poor fellow out on his five wits,
And seven senses? Do not weep Iohn Clay.
I swear the poor wretch is as guilty from it,
As the Child was, was born this very morning.
No, as I am a Christian soul, would I were hanged
If ever I -- alas I! would I were out
Of my life, so I would I were, and in
again --
Nay, Mrs. Awdrey will say nay to that.
No, In-and-out? if you were out of your life,
How should she do for a husband? who should fall
Aboard of her then, Ball? He is a Puppy?
No; Hanniball has no breeding: well! I say little,
But hitherto all goes well, pray it prove no better.
Come Father; I would we were married: I am a-cold.
Well, Mr. Constable, this your fine Groom here,
Bridegroom, or what Groom else, soever he be,
I charge him with the felony; and charge you
To carry him back forthwith to Paddington,
Unto my Captain, who stays my return there:
I am to go to the next Justice of peace,
To get a warrant to raise Hue and Cry,
And bring him, and his fellows all before
him.
Fare you well Sir, and look to him I charge you,
As you will answer it. Take heed; the business
If you defer, may prejudicial you
More than you think-for, say I told you so.
Here is a Bride-ale indeed! Ah son Iohn, son Clay!
I little thought you would have proved a piece
Of such false metal.
Father, will you believe me?
Would I might never stir in my new shoes,
If ever I would do so foul a fact.
Well Neighbours, I do charge you to assist me
With him to Paddington. Be he a true man, so:
The better for him. I will do mine office,
If he were my own begotten a thousand
times.
Why, do you hear man? Husband? Mr. Turfe!
What shall my Daughter do? Puppy, stay here.

stage.l: She follows her husband. and neighbours.

sp.l: Mother, I will go with you, and with my Father.
Nay, stay sweet Mrs. Awdrey: here are none
But one friend (as they say) desires to speak
A word, or two, cold with you: How do you feel
Yourself this frosty morning?
What have you
To do to ask, I pray you? I am a-cold.
It seems you are hot, good Mrs. Awdrey.
You lie; I am as cold as Ice is: Feel else.
Nay, you have cooled my courage: I am past it,
I have done feeling with you.
Done with me?
I do defy you. So I do, to say,
You have done with me: you are a saucy Puppy.
O you mistake! I meant not as you mean.
Meant you not knavery, Puppy?
No: not I.
Clay meant you all the knavery, it seems,
Who rather, than he would be married to you,
Chose to be wedded to the Gallows first.
I thought he was a dissembler; he would prove
A slippery Merchant in the frost. He might
Have married one first, and have been hanged after,
If he had had a mind to it. But you men,
Fie on you.
Mrs. Awdrey, can you find,
In your heart to fancy Puppy? me poor Ball?
You are disposed to jeer one, Mr. Hanniball.
Pity on me! the angry man with the beard!
Put on thy hat, I look for no despect.
Where is thy Master?
Marry, he is gone
With the picture of despair, to Paddington.
Prithee run after him, and tell him he shall
Find out my Captain, lodged at the red-Lyon
In Paddington, that is the Inn. Let him ask
For Captain Thum's; and take that for thy pains:
He may seek long enough else. Hie thee again.
Yes, Sir you will look to Mrs. Bride the while?
That I will: prithee haste.
What Puppy? Puppy?
Sweet Mrs. Bride, He will come again
presently.
Here was no subtle device to get a wench.
This Canon has a brave pate of his own!
A shaven pate! And a right monger, in faith!
This was his plot! I follow Captain Thum's?
We robbed in Saint Iohn's wood? In my the other hose!
I laugh, to think what a fine fools finger they have
O this wise Constable, in pricking out
This Captain Thum's to his neighbours: you shall see
The Tile-man too set fire on his own
Kill,
And leap into it, to save himself from hanging.
You talk of a Bride-ale, here was a Bride-ale broke,
In the nick. Well: I must yet dispatch this Bride,
To mine own master, the young
Squire, and then
My task is done. Gentlewoman! I have in sort
Done you some wrong, but now I will do you what right
I can: It is true, you are a proper woman;
But to be cast away on such a Clowne-pipe
As Clay; methinks, your friends are not so wise
As nature might have made them; well, go to:
There is better fortune coming toward you;
If you do not deject it. Take a fool's
Counsel, and do not stand in your own
light.
It may prove better than you think for: Look you.
Alas Sir, what is it you would have me do?
I would fain do all for the best, if I knew how.
Forsake not a good turn, when it is offered you;
Fair Mistress Awdrey, that is your name, I take it.
No Mistress, Sir, my name is Awdrey.
Well, so it is, there is a bold young Squire,
The blood of Totten, Tub, and Tripoly --.
Squire Tub, you mean? I know him: he knows me too.
He is in love with you: and more, he is mad for you.
Aye, so he told me: in his wits, I think.
But he is too fine for me; and has a Lady
Tub to his Mother. Here he comes himself!
O you are a trusty Governor!
What ails you?
You do not know when you are well, I think:
You would have the Calf with the white face, Sir, would you?
I have her for you here; what would you more?
Quietness, Hilts, and hear no more of it.
No more of it, quoth you? I do not care,
If some of us had not heard so much of it,
I tell you true; A man must carry, and vetch, --
Like Bungy's dog for you.
What is he?
A Spaniel.
And scarce be spit in the mouth for it. A good Dog
Deserves, Sir, a good bone, of a free Master:
But, if your turns be served, the devil a bit
You care for a man after, ere a Lard of you.
Like will to like, in faith, quoth the scabbed Squire
To the mangy Knight, when both met in a dish
Of buttered fish. One bad, there is never
a good;
And not a barrel better Herring among you.
Nay Hilts! I pray thee grow not frampold now.
Turn not the bad Cow, after thy good soap.
Our plot hath hitherto taken good effect:
And should it now be troubled, or stopped up,
It would prove the utter ruin of my hopes.
I pray thee haste to Pancridge, to the Canon:
And give him notice of our good success;
Will him that all things be in readiness.
Fair Awdrey, and myself, will
cross the fields,
The nearest path. Good Hilts, make thou some haste,
And meet us on the way. Come gentle Awdrey.
Faith, would I had a few more geances on it:
If you say the word, send me to Iericho.
Out-cept a man were a Post-horse, I have not known
The like on it; yet, if he had kind words,
It would never irk him. But a man may break
His heart out in these days, and get a slap
With a fox-tail, when he has done. And there is all.
Nay, say not so Hilts: hold thee; there are Crowns --
My love bestows on thee, for thy reward.
If Gold will please thee, all my land shall drop
In bounty thus, to recompense thy merit.
Tut, keep your land, and your gold too Sir: I
Seek neither -- nother of them. Learn to get
More: you will know to spend that sum you have
Early enough: you are assured of me.
I love you too too well, to live on the spoil:
For your own sake, were there were
no worse than I.
All is not Gold that glisters: I will to Pancridge.
See, how his love doth melt him into Tears!
An honest faithful servant is a Jewel.
Now the adventurous Squire hath time, and leisure,
To ask his Awdrey how she does, and hear
A grateful answer from her. She not speaks:
Hath the proud Tiran, Frost, usurped the feat
Of former beauty in my Loves fair cheek;
Staining the roseate tincture of her blood,
With the dull die of blue-congealing cold?
No, sure the weather dares not so presume
To hurt an object of her brightness. Yet,
The more I view her, she but looks so, so.
Ha? give me leave to search this mystery!
O now I have it: Bride, I know your grief;
The last nights cold, hath bred in you such horror
Of the assigned Bridegrooms constitution,
The Kilborne Clay-pit; that frost-bitten marl;
That lump in courage: melting cake of Ice;
That the conceit thereof hath almost killed thee.
But I must do thee good wench, and refresh thee.
You are a merry man, Squire Tub, of Totten!
I have heard much of your words, but not of your deeds.
Thou sayst true, sweet, I have been too slack in deeds.
Yet, I was never so straight-laced to you, Squire.
Why, did you ever love me, gentle Awdrey?
Love you? I cannot tell: I must hate nobody,
My Father says.
Yes, Clay, and Kilburne; Awdrey,
You must hate them.
It shall be for your sake then.
And for my sake, shall yield you that gratuity.
Soft, and fair, Squire, there go two word's to a bargain.
What are those Awdrey?
Nay, I cannot tell.
My Mother said, sure, if you married me,
You would make me a Lady the first week: and put me
In, I know not what, the very day.
What was it?
Speak gentle Awdrey, thou shalt have it yet.
A velvet dressing for my head, it is,
They say will make one brave: I will not know
Besse Moale, nor Margery Turne-up: I will look
Another way upon them, and be proud.
Troth I could wish my wench a better wit;
But what she wanteth there, her face supplies.
There is a pointed lustre in her eye
Hath shot quite through me, and hath hit my heart:
And thence it is, I first received the wound,
That rankles now, which only she can cure.
Fain would I work myself, from
this conceit;
But, being flesh, I cannot. I must love her,
The naked truth is: and I will go on,
Were it for nothing, but to cross my Rivals.
Come Awdrey: I am now resolved to have thee.
Nay, do it quickly, Miles; why shakest thou man?
Speak but his name: I will second thee
What is his name?
Squire Tripoly or Tub.
Squire Tub, I do arrest you
In the Queens Majesties name, and all the Councils.
Arrest me, Varlet?
Keep the peace I charge you.
Are you there, Justice Bramble? where is your warrant?
The warrant is directed here to me,
From the whole table; wherefore I would pray you
Be patient Squire, and make good the peace.
Well, at your pleasure, Justice. I am wronged:
Sirrah, what are you have arrested me?
He is a Pursuivant at Arms, Squire Tub.
I am a Pursuivant, see, by my Coat else.
Well Pursuivant, go with me: I will give you bail.
Sir he may take no bail. It is a warrant,
In special from the Council, and commands
Your personal appearance. Sir, your weapon
I must require: And then deliver you
A Prisoner to this officer, Squire Tub.
I pray you to conceive of me no other,
Than as your friend, and neighbour. Let my person
Be severed from my office in the fact,
And I am clear. Here Pursuivant, receive him
Into your hands; and use him like a Gentleman.
I thank you Sir: But whither must I go now?
Nay, that must not be told you, till you come
Unto the place assigned by his instructions.
I will be the Maidens Convoy to her father,
For this time, Squire.
I thank you Mr. Bramble.
I doubt, or fear, you will make her the balance
To weigh your Justice in. Pray ye do me right,
And lead not her, at least out of the way.
Justice is blind, and having a blind Guide,
She may be apt to slip aside.
I will see to her:
I see my wooing will not thrive. Arrested!
As I had set my rest up, for a wife?
And being so fair for it, as I was -- Well, fortune,
Thou art a blind Bawd, and a Beggar too,
To cross me thus; and let my only
Rival,
To get her from me? That is the spite of spites.
But most I muse at, is, that I, being none
Of the Court, am sent for thither by the Council!
My heart is not so light, as it was in the morning.
You mean to make a Hoyden, or a Hare
O me, to hunt Counter thus, and makes these doubles:
And you mean no such thing, as you send about?
Where is your sweet-heart now, I marl?
O Hilts!
I know you of old! never halt
before a Cripple.
Will you have a Caudle? where is your grief, Sir? speak?
Do you hear friend? Do you serve this Gentleman?
How then, Sir? what if I do? peradventure yea:
Peradventure nay, what is that to you Sir? Say.
Nay, pray you Sir, I meant no harm in truth:
But this good Gentleman is arrested.
How?
Say me that again.
Nay Basket, never storm;
I am arrested here, upon command
From the Queens Council, and I must obey.
You say Sir very true, you must obey.
An honest Gentleman, in faith!
He must?
But that which most tormenteth me, is this,
That Justice Bramble hath got hence my Awdrey.
How? how? stand by a little, sirrah, you
With the bade of your breast. Let us know Sir what you
are?
I am Sir (pray you do not look so terribly)
A Pursuivant.
A Pursuivant? your name Sir?
My name Sir --
What is it? speak?
Miles Metaphor;
And Justice Preambles Clarke.
What says he?
Pray you,
Let him alone. You are a Pursuivant?
No faith, Sir, would I might never stir from you,
I is made a Pursuivant against my will.
Ha! and who made you one? tell true, or my will
Shall make you nothing, instantly.
Put up
Your frightful Blade; and your dead-doing look,
And I shall tell you all.
Speak then the truth,
And the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.
My Master, Justice Bramble, hearing your Master,
The Squire Tub, was coming on this way,
With Mrs. Awdrey, the high Constables Daughter;
Made me a Pursuivant: and gave me warrant
To arrest him, so that he might get the Lady,
With whom he is gone to Pancridge, to the Vicar,
Not to her Fathers. This was the device,
Which I beseech you, do not tell my Master.
O wonderful! well Basket, let him rise:
And for my free escape, forge some excuse.
I will post to Paddington, to acquaint old Turfe,
With the whole business, and so stop the marriage.
Well, bless thee: I do wish thee grace, to keep
Thy Masters secrets, better, or be hanged.
I thank you, for your gentle admonition.
Pray you, let me call you God-father hereafter.
And as your Godson Metaphore I promise,
To keep my Masters privities, sealed up
In the valleys on my trust, locked close for ever,
Or let me be trussed up at Tiburne shortly.
Thine own wish, save, or choke thee;
Come away.

stage.l: Turfe. Clench. Medlay. To-Pan. Scriben. Clay.

sp.l: Passion of me, was ever man thus crossed?
All things run Arse-Varsie; upside down.
High Constable! Now by our Lady of Walsingham.
I had rather be marked out Tom Scavenger:
And with a shovel make clean the high ways,
Than have this office of a Constable,
And a high Constable! The higher charge
It brings more trouble, more vexation with it.
Neighbours, good neighbours, advise me what to do:
How we shall bear us in this Hue and Cry.
We cannot find the Captain; no such man
Lodged at the Lion, nor came thither hurt.
The morning we have spent in privy search;
And by that means the Bride-ale is differed;
The Bride, she is left alone in Puppy's charge;
The Bridegroom goes under a pair of sureties;
And held of all as a respected person.
How should we bustle forward? Give some counsel,
How to bestir our stumps in these cross ways.
Faith Gossip Turfe, you have, you say, Remission,
To comprehend all such, as are suspected:
Now, would I make another privy search
Through this Town, and then you have searched two towns.
Masters, take heed, let us not find too many:
One is enough to stay the Hang-mans stomach.
There is Iohn Clay, who is found already;
A proper man: A Tile-man by his trade:
A man as one would say, moulded in clay:
As spruce as any neighbours child among you:
And he (you see) is taken on conspiracy,
And two, or three (they say) what call you them?
Such as the Justices of Coram nobis.
Grant -- (I forget their names, you have many of them,
Mr. High Constable they come to you.)
I have it at my tongues end -- Cunni-borroughes,
To bring him straight afore the sessions house.
O you mean warrens, neighbour, do you not?
Aye, aye, thick same! you know them well enough.
Too well, too well, would I have never known them.
We good free-holders cannot live in quiet,
But every hour new precepts, Hues and Cries,
Put us to requisitions night and day:
What should a man say, should we leave the search?
I am in danger, to burse as much
As he was robbed of; aye, and pay his hurts,
If I should follow it, all the good cheer
That was provided; for the wedding dinner
Is spoiled, and lost. O there are two vat pigs,
A zindging by the vier: Now by Saint Tomy,
Too good to eat, but on a wedding day;
And then, a Goose will bid you all, Come cut me.
Sun Clay, sun Clay (for I must call thee so)
Be of good comfort; take my Muckender;
And dry thine eyes. If thou beest true, and honest;
And if thou findest thy conscience clear from it,
Pluck up a good heart, we will do well enough.
If not, confess in truths name. But in faith
I durst be sworn upon all holy books,
Iohn Clay would never commit a
On his own head.
No; Truth is my rightful Judge:
I have kept my hands, here hence, from evil speaking,
Lying, and slandering; and my tongue from stealing.
He do not live this day can say, Iohn Clay
I have seen thee, but in the way of honesty.
Faith neighbour Medlay I durst be his borough,
He would not look a true man in the face.
I take the town to concord, where I dwell,
All Kilburne be my witness; If I were not
Begot in bashfulness, brought up in shamefacedness:
Let him bring a dog, but to my face, that can
Say, I have beat him, and without a vault;
Or but a cat, will swear upon a book,
I have as much as set afire her tail;
And I will give him, or her a crown for amends.
But to give out, and say, I have robbed a Captain!
Receive me at the latter day, if I
Ever thought of any such matter; or
could mind it --.
No Iohn, you are come of too good personage,
I think my Gossip Clench, and Mr. Turfe
Both think, you would attempt no such foul matter.
But how unhappily it comes to pass!
Just on the wedding day! I cry me mercy:
I had almost forgot the Hue and Cry:
Good neighbour Pan, you are the Third-burrow,
And Diogenes Scriben, you my learned Writer,
Make out a new precept -- Lord, for thy goodness,
I had forgot my Daughter, all this while;
The idle knave hath brought no news from her.
Here comes the sneaking Puppy; What is the news?
My heart! my heart! I fear all is not well,
Some things mishapped, that he is come without her.
O, where is my Master? my Master? my Master?
Thy Master? what wouldst with thy Master, man?
There is thy Mr.
What is the matter Puppy?
O Master! o Dame! o Dame! o Master!
What sayst thou to thy Master, or thy Dame?
O Iohn Clay! Iohn Clay! Iohn Clay!
What of Iohn Clay?
Luck grant he bring not news he shall be hanged.
The world forfend, I hope, it is not so well.
O Lord! o me! what shall I do? poor Iohn!
O Iohn Clay! Iohn Clay! Iohn Clay!
Alas,
That ever I was born! I will not stay by it,
For all the Tiles in Kilburne.
What of Clay?
Speak Puppy, what of him?
He hath lost, he hath lost.
for luck sake speak, Puppy, what hath he lost?
O Awdrey, Awdrey, Awdrey!
What of my daughter
Awdrey?
I tell you Awdrey -- do you understand me?
Sweet Master! Awdrey, my dear Dame --
Where is she? what is become of her, I pray thee?
O the serving-man! the serving-man! the serving-man!
What talkest thou of the serving-man? where is Awdrey?
Gone with the serving-man, gone with the serving-man.
Good Puppy, whither is she gone with him?
I cannot tell, he bad me bring you word,
The Captain lay at the Lion, and before
I came again, Awdrey was gone with
the serving-man;
I tell you, Awdrey is run away with the serving-man.
Oddsocks! my woman, what shall we do now?
Now, so you help not, man, I know not, I.
This was your pomp of Maids: I told you of it.
Six Maids to follow you, and not leave one
To wait upon your Daughter: I said, Pride
Would be paid one day, her old vi'pence, wife.
What of Iohn Clay, Ball Puppy?
He hath lost --
His life for felony?
No, his wife by villainy.
Now, villains both! o that same Hue and Cry!
O neighbours! o what cursed serving-man!
O maids! O wife!
But Iohn Clay, where is he?
How! fled for fear, say ye? will he slip us now?
We that are sureties, must require him out.
How shall we do to find the serving-man?
Cocks bodkins! we must not lose Iohn Clay:
Awdrey, my daughter Awdrey too! let us send
To all the towns, and seek her; but alas,
The Hue and Cry, that must be looked unto.
What, in a passion Turfe?
Aye good Squire Tub.
Were never honest farmers thus perplexed.
Turfe, I am privy to thy deep unrest:
The ground of which, springs from an idle plot,
Cast by a Suitor, to your daughter Awdrey--
And thus much, Turfe, let me advertise you;
Your daughter Awdrey, met I on the way,
With Justice Bramble in her company:
Who means to marry her at Pancridge Church.
And there is Cannon Hugh, to meet them ready:
Which to prevent you must not trust delay;
But winged speed must cross their sly intent:
Then hie thee. Turfe, haste to forbid the Banes.
Hath Justice Bramble got my daughter Awdrey?
A little while, shall he enjoy her, sure.
But O the Hue and Cry! that hinders me:
I must pursue that, or neglect my journey:
I will even leave all: and with the
patient Ass,
The over-laden Ass, throw off my burden,
And cast mine office; pluck in my large ears
Betimes, lest some mis-judge them to be horns:
I will leave to beat it on the broken hoof,
And ease my pasterns. I will no more High Constables.
I cannot choose, but smile, to see thee troubled
With such a bald, half-hatched circumstance!
The Captain was not robbed, as is reported;
That trick the Justice craftily devised,
To break the marriage with the Tile-man Clay.
The Hue, and Cry, was merely counterfeit:
The rather may you judge it to be such,
Because the Bridegroom, was described to be
One of the thieves, first in the felony.
Which, how far it is from him,
yourselves may guess:
It was Justice Bramble's vetch, to get the wench.
And is this true Squire Tub?
Believe me, Turfe,
As I am a Squire: or less, a Gentleman.
I take my office back: and my authority,
Upon your worships words. Neighbours, I am
High Constable again: where is my
son Clay?
He shall be son, yet, wife, your meat by leisure:
Draw back the spits.
That is done already man.
I will break this marriage off: and afterward,
She shall be given to her first betrothed.
I will follow him aloof, to see the event.
Dame, Mistress, though I do not turn the spit;
I hope yet the Pigs-head.
Come up, Jack-sauce:
It shall be served in to you.
No, no service,
But a reward for service.
I still took you
For an unmannerly Puppy: will you come,
And vetch more wood for the vier, Mr. Ball?
I wood to the vier? I shall piss it out first:
You think to make me even your ox,
or ass;
Or anything. Though I cannot
right myself
On you; I will sure revenge me on your meat.
Madam, to Kentish Town, we are got at length;
But, by the way we cannot meet the Squire:
Nor by inquiry can we hear of him.
Here is Turfe's house, the father of the Maid.
Pol-Marten, see, the streets are strewed with herbs,
And here hath been a wedding, Wisp, it seems!
Pray heaven, this Bridal be not for my son!
Good Marten, knock: knock quickly: Ask for Turfe.
My thoughts missive me, I am in such a doubt --
Who keeps the house here?
Why the door, and walls
Do keep the house.
I ask then, who is within?
Not you that are without.
Look forth, and speak
Into the street, here. Come before my Lady.
Before my Lady? Lord have mercy upon me:
If I do come before her, she will see
The handsomest man in all the Town, pardy!
Now stand I for her, what saith velvet she?
Sirrah, whose man are you?
Madam, my Masters.
And who is thy Master?
What you tread on, Madam.
I tread on an old Turfe.
That Turfe is my Master.
A merry fellow! what is thy name?
Ball Puppy
They call me at home: abroad Hanniball Puppy.
Come hither, I must kiss thee, Valentine Puppy.
Wisp! have you got you a Valentine?
None, Madam;
He is the first stranger that I saw.
To me
He is so, and such. Let us share him equally.
Help, help good Dame. A rescue, and in time.
in stead of Bills, with Costaves come: in stead of Spears,
with Spits;
Your slices serve for slicing swords, to save me, and my
wits:
A Lady, and her woman here, their Usher eke by side,
(But he stands mute) have plotted how your Puppy to divide.
How now? what noise is this with you, Ball Puppy?
O Dame! And fellows of the Kitchen! Arm,
Arm, for my safety; if you love your Ball:
Here is a strange thing, called a Lady, a Mad-dame:
And a device of hers, yclept her woman;
Have plotted on me, in the Kings high-way,
To steal me from myself, and
cut me in halves,
To make one Valentine to serve them both;
This for my right-side, that my left-hand love.
So saucy, Puppy? to use no more reverence
Unto my Lady, and her velvet Gown?
Turfe's wife, rebuke him not: Your man doth please me
With his conceit. Hold: there are ten old nobles,
To make thee merrier yet, half-Valentine.
I thank you right-side: could my left as much
It would make me a man of mark: young Hanniball!
Dido, shall make that good; or I will for her.
Here Dido Wisp, there is for your Hanniball:
He is your Countryman, as well as Valentine.
Here Mr. Hanniball: my Ladies bounty
for her poor woman, Wisp.
Brave Carthage Queen!
And such was Dido: I will ever be
Champion to her, who Iuno is to thee.
Your Ladyship is very welcome here.
Please yon, good Madam, to go near the house
Turfe's wife, I come thus far to seek thy husband,
Having some business to impart unto him.
Is he at home?
O no, if it shall please you:
He is posted hence to Pancridge with a witness.
Young Justice Bramble has kept level coil
Here in our Quarters, stole away our Daughter,
And Mr. Turfe is run after, as he can,
To stop the marriage, if it will be stopped.
Madam, these tidings are not much amiss!
For if the Justice have the Maid in keep,
You need not fear the marriage of your son.
That somewhat easeth my suspicious breast.
Tell me, Turfe's wife, when was my son with Awdrey?
How long is it, since you saw him at your house?
Dame, let me take this rump out of your mouth.
What mean you by that Sir?
Rump, and tail is all one.
But I would use a reverence for my Lady:
I would not say surreverence, the tale
Out on your mouth, but rather take the rump.
A well bred youth! and full of favour you are:
What might they say, when I were gone, if I
Not weighed my words? this Puppy is a fool!
Great Hanniball is an Ass; he had no breeding:
No Lady gay, you shall not say,
That your Val. Puppy, was so unlucky,
In speech to fail, as to name a tail,
Be as be may be, before a fair Lady.
Leave jesting, tell us, when you saw our son.
Marry, it is two hours ago.
Since you saw him?
You might have seen him too, if you had looked up.
For it shined, as bright as day.
Mean my son.
Your sun, and our sun are they not all one?
Fool, thou mistakest; I asked thee, for my son!
I had thought there had been no more suns, than one.
I know not what you Ladies have, or may have.
Didst thou never
hear, my Lady had a son?
She may have twenty; but for a son, unless
She mean precisely, Squire Tub, her son,
He was here now; and brought my Mr. word
That Justice Bramble had got Mrs. Awdrey.
But wither he be gone, here is none can tell.
Marten, I wonder at this strange discourse:
The fool it seems tells true; my son the Squire
Was doubtless here this morning. For the match,
I will smother what I think, and staying here,
Attend the sequel of this strange beginning,
Turfe's wife; my people, and I will trouble thee:
Until we hear some tidings of thy husband.
The rather, for my party Valentine.
Well, I have carried it, and will triumph
Over this Justice, as becomes a Constable;
And a high Constable: next our Saint George,
Who rescued the Kings Daughter, I will ride;
Above Prince Arthur.
Or our Shore-ditch Duke.
Or Pancridge Earl.
Or Bevis, or Sir Guy.
Who were high Constables both.
One of Southhampton --.
The the other of Warwick-Castle.
You shall work it
Into a story for me, neighbour Medlay,
Over my Chimney.
I can give you Sir,
A Roman story of a petty-Constable,
That had a Daughter, that was called Virginia,
Like Mrs. Awdrey, and as young as she;
And how her Father bare him in the business,
Against Justice Appius, a Decemvir
in Rome,
And Justice of Assize.
That, that good Diogenes!
A learned man is a Chronicle!
I can tell you
A thousand, of great Pompei, Trajan,
All the high Constables there.
That was their place:
They were no more.
Dictator, and high Constable
Were both the same.
High Constable was more, though!
He laid Dick: Tator by the heels.
Dick: Toter!
He was one of the Weights of the City: I have read of him:
He was a fellow would be drunk, debauched --
And he did set one in the stocks indeed:
His name Vadian, and a cunning Toter.
Was ever silly Maid thus posted off?
That should have had three husbands in one day;
Yet (by bad fortune) am possessed of none?
I went to Church to have been wed to Clay;
Then Squire Tub he seized me on the way,
And thought to have had me: but he missed his aim;
And Justice Bramble (nearest of the three)
Was well nigh married to me; when by chance,
In rushed my Father, and broke off that dance.
Aye, Girl, there is never a Justice
on them all,
Shall teach the Constable to guard his
own:
Let us back to Kentish-Towne, and there make merry;
These news will be glad tidings to my wife:
Thou shalt have Clay, my wench. That word shall stand.
He is found by this time, sure, or else he is drowned:
The wedding dinner will be spoiled: make haste.
Husbands, they say, grow thick; but thin are sown,
I care not who it be, so I have one.
Aye? say you so? Perhaps you shall have none, for
that.
Now out on me! what shall I do then?
Sleep Mistress Awdrey, dream on proper men.
O bone Deus! have you seen the like?
Here was, Hodge hold thine ear, fair, whilst I strike.
Body of me, how came this gear about?
I know not, Canon, but it falls out cross.
Nor can I make conjecture by the circumstance
Of these events; it was impossible,
Being so close and politically carried,
To come so quickly to the ears of Turfe.
O Priest, had but thy slow delivery
Been nimble, and thy lazy Latin tongue,
But run the forms over, with
that swift dispatch,
As had been requisite, all had been well!
What should have been, that never loved the Friar;
But thus you see the old Adage verified,
Multa cadunt inter -- you can guess the rest.
Many things fall between the cup, and lip:
And though they touch, you are not sure to drink.
You lacked good fortune, we had done our parts:
Give a man fortune, throw him in the Sea.
The properer man, the worse luck: Stay a time;
Tempus edax -- In time the stately Ox, etc.
Good counsels lightly never come too late.
You Sir will run your counsels out of breath.
Spur a free horse, he will run himself to death.
Sancti Evangelistæ! Here come Miles!
What news man, with our new made Pursuivant?
A Pursuivant? would I were, or more pursie,
And had more store of money; or less pursie,
And had more store of breath: you call me Pursuivant!
But, I could never vant of any purse
I had, since you were my God-fathers,
and God-mothers,
And gave me that nick-name.
What, now is the matter?
Nay, it is no matter. I have been simply beaten.
What is become of the Squire, and thy Prisoner?
The lines of blood, ran streaming from my head,
Can speak what rule the Squire hath kept with me.
I pray thee Miles relate the manner, how?
Be it known unto you, by these presents, then,
That I Miles Metaphore, your worships Clarke:
Have even been beaten, to an
Allegory,
By multitude of hands. Had they been but
Some five or six, I had whipped them all, like tops
In Lent, and hurled them into Hoblers-hole;
Or the next ditch: I had cracked all their costards,
As nimbly as a Squirrel will crack nuts:
And flourished like to Hercules, the Porter
Among the Pages. But, when they came on
Like Bees about a Hive, Crows about carrion,
Flies about sweet meats; nay, like water-men
About a Fare: then was poor Metaphore
Glad to give up the honour of the day,
To quite his charge to them, and run away
To save his life, only to tell
this news.
How indirectly all things have fallen out!
I cannot choose but wonder what they were
Rescued your rival from the keep of Miles:
But most of all I cannot well digest,
The manner how our purpose came to Turfe.
Miles, I will see that all thy hurts be dressed.
As for the Squires escape, it matters not:
We have by this means disappointed him;
And that was all the maine I aimed at.
But Canon Hugh, now muster up thy wits,
And call thy thoughts into the Consistory.
Search all the secret corners of thy cap,
To find another quaint devised drift,
To disappoint her marriage with this Clay;
Do that, and I will reward thee jovially.
Well said Magister Justice. If I fit you not
With such a new, and well-laid stratagem,
As never yet your ears did hear a finer,
Call me, with Lily, Bos, Fur, Sus, atq; Sacerdos.
I hear, there is comfort in thy words yet, Canon.
I will trust thy regulars, and say no more.
I will follow too. And if the dapper Priest
Be but as cunning, point in his devise,
As I was in my lie: my Master Preamble
Will stalk, as led by the nose with these new promises,
And fatted with supposes of fine hopes.

stage.l: Turfe. D. Turfe. L. Tub. Pol-mart. Awd. Pup.

sp.l: Well Madam, I may thank the Squire your son:
For, but for him, I had been overreached.
Now heavens blessing light upon his heart:
We are beholden to him, indeed Madam.
But can you not resolve me where he is?
Nor about what his purposes were bent?
Madam, they no whit were concerning me:
And therefore was I less inquisitive.
Fair maid, in faith, speak truth, and not dissemble:
Does he not often come, and visit you?
His worship now, and then, please you, takes pains
To see my Father, and Mother: But for me,
I know myself too mean for his
high thoughts
To stoop at, more than asking a light question,
To make him merry, or to pass his time.
A sober Maid! call for my woman Marten.
The maids, and her half-Valentine have plied her
With curtsy of the Bride-Cake, and the Bowl,
As she is laid awhile.
O let her rest!
Canterbury, in the interim;
And to make home. Farewell good Turfe, and thy wife.
I wish your daughter joy.
Thanks to your Ladyship,
Where is Iohn Clay now? have you seen him yet?
No, he has hid himself out of the way,
For fear of the Hue and cry.
What, walks that shadow
Afore him still? Puppy go seek him out,
Search all the corners that he haunts unto,
And call him forth. We will once more to the
Church,
And try or fortunes. Luck, son Valentine:
Where are the wise-men all of Finzbury?
Where wise-men should be; at the Ale, and Bride-cake.
I would this couple had their destiny,
Or to be hanged, or married out of the way:
Man cannot get the mountenance of an Eggshell,
To stay his stomach.
Faith, for mine own part,
I have supped up so much broth, as would have covered
A leg of Beef, over head and ears,
in the porridge pot:
And yet I cannot satisfy wild nature.
Would they were once despatched, we might to dinner.
I am with child of a huge stomach, and long;
till by some honest Midwife-piece of Beef,
I be delivered of it: I must go now,
And hunt out for this Kilburne Calf, Iohn Clay:
Whom were to find, I know not, nor which way.
Thus as a beggar in a Kings disguise,
Or an old Cross well sided with a May-pole.
Comes Canon Hugh, accoutred as you see
Disguised Soldado-like: mark his devise:
The Canon, is that Captain Thum's, was robbed:
These bloody scars upon my face are wounds;
This scarf upon mine arm shows my late hurts
And thus am I to gull the Constable.
Now have among you, for a man at arms:
Friends by your leave, which of you is one Turfe?
Sir, I am Turfe, if you would speak with me.
With thee Turfe, if thou beest High Constable.
I am both Turfe, Sir and High Constable.
Then Turfe, or Scurf, high, or low Constable:
Know, I was once a Captain at Saint Quintins,
And passing cross the ways over the country,
This morning betwixt this and Hamsted-Heath,
Was by a crew of Clowns robbed, bobbed, and hurt.
No sooner had I got my wounds bound up,
But with much pain, I went to the next Justice,
One Mr. Bramble here, at Maribone:
And here a warrant is, which he hath directed
For you one Turfe; if your name be Tobie Turfe;
Who have let fall (they say) the Hue and Cry;
And you shall answer it before the
Justice.
Heaven, and Hell, Dogs, Devils, what is this?
Neighbours, was ever Constable thus crossed?
What shall we do?
Faith, all go hang ourselves:
I know no other way to scape the Law.
News, news, O news --
What, hast thou found out Clay?
No Sir, the news is that I cannot find him.
Why do you dally, you damned russet coat,
You Peasant, nay you Clown, you Constable;
See that you bring forth the suspected party,
Or by mine honour (which I won in field)
I will make you pay for it, before
the Justice.
Fie, fie; O wife, I am now in a fine pickle.
He that was most suspected is not found;
And which now makes me think, he did the deed,
He thus absents him, and dares not be seen.
Captain, my innocence will plead for me.
Wife, I must go, needs, whom the Devil drives:
Pray for me wife, and daughter; pray for me.
I will lead the way: Thus is the match put off,
And if my plot succeed, as I have laid it,
My Captainship shall cost him many a crown.
So, we have brought our eggs to a fair
Market.
Out on that villain Clay: would he do a robbery?
I will never trust smooth-faced
Tile-man for his sake.
Mother, the still Sow eats up all the draff.
Thus is my Master, Toby Turfe, the pattern
Of all the painful adventures, now in print.
I never could hope better of this match:
This Bride-ale: For the night before today,
(Which is within man's memory, I take it)
At the report of it, an Ox did speak;
Who died soon after: A Cow lost her Calf:
The Bellwether was flayed for it: A fat Hog
Was singed, and washed, and shaven all over; to
Look ugly against this day: The
Ducks they quaked;
The Hens too cackled: at the nose whereof,
A Drake was seen to dance a headless round:
The Goose was cut in the head, to hear it too:
Brave Chant-it-cleare, his noble heart was done;
His comb was cut: And two or three of his wives,
Or fairest Concubines, had their necks broke,
Ere they would see this day: To mark the fervent
Heart of a beast, the very Pig, the Pig,
This very morning, as he was aroasting
Cried out his eyes, and made a show as he would
Have bit in two the spit, as he would say;
There shall no roast-meat be this dismal day.
And sure, I think, If I had not got his tongue
Between my teeth, and eat it, he had spoke it.
Well, I will in, and cry too, never leave
Crying, until our maids may drive a Buck
With my salt tears at the next washing day.
Keep out those fellows; I will have none come in,
But the High Constable, the man of peace,
And the Queens Captain, the brave man of war.
Now neighbour Turfe, the cause why you are called,
Before me by my warrant, but unspecified,
Is this; and pray you mark it thoroughly!
Here is a Gentleman, and as it seems,
Both of good birth, fair speech, and peaceable,
Who was this morning robbed here in the wood:
You for your part a man of good report,
Of credit, landed, and of fair demeans,
And by authority, high Constable;
Are not withstanding touched in this complaint,
Of being careless in the Hue and Cry.
I cannot choose but grieve a Soldiers loss:
And I am sorry too for your neglect,
Being my neighbour; this is all I object.
This is not all; I can allege far more,
And almost urge him for an accessory.
Good Mr. Justice give me leave to speak,
For I am Plaintiff. Let not neighbour-hood
Make him secure, or stand on privilege.
Sir, I dare use no partiality:
Object then what you please, so it be truth.
This more: and which is more, than he can answer,
Beside his letting fall the Hue and Cry
He doth protect the man, charged with the felony,
And keeps him hid I hear, within his house,
Because he is affied unto his Daughter.
I do defy him, so shall she do too.
I pray your worships favour, let me have hearing.
I do confess, it was told me such a felony,
And it not disgrieved me a little when it was told me,
For I was going to Church, to marry Awdrey:
And who should marry her, but this very Clay,
Who was charged to be the chief thief of them all.
Now I (the halter stick me, if I tell,
Your worships any leazins did fore-think him
The truest man, till he was run away.
I thought, I had had him as sure as in a saw-pit,
Or in mine Oven. Nay, in the Town-pound.
I was so sure of him: I would have given my life for
him,
Till he did start. But now, I see him guilty,
As far as I can look at him. Would you have more?
Yes, I will have Sir what the Law will give me.
You gave your word to see him safe, forth coming;
I challenge that: But, that is forfeited;
Beside, your carelessness in the pursuit,
Argues your slackness, and neglect of duty,
Which ought be punished with severity.
He speaks but reason Turfe. Bring forth the man,
And you are quit: But otherwise, your word
Binds you to make amends for all his loss,
And think yourself befriended,
if he take it
Without a farther suit, or going to law.
Come to a composition with him, Turfe:
The Law is costly, and will draw on charge.
Yes, I do know, I first must fee a attorney,
And then make legs to my great man of Law,
To be of my counsel, and take trouble-vees,
And yet say nothing for me, but devise
All district means, to ransack me of my money.
A Pestilence prick the throats of them. I do know hun
As well as I was in their bellies, and brought up there.
What would you have me do? what would you ask of me?
I ask the restitution of my money;
And will not bate one penny of the sum:
Four score, and five pound. I ask, besides,
Amendment for my hurts; my pain, and suffering
Are loss enough for me, Sir, to sit
down with;
I will put it to your worship; what you award me,
I will take; and give him a general release.
And what say you now, neighbour Turfe?
I put it
Even to your worships bitterment,
hab, nab.
I shall have a chance of the dice for it, I hope, let them
even run: And --
Faith then I will pray you, because
he is my neighbour,
To take a hundred pound, and give him day.
Saint Valentines day, I will, this very day,
Before Sun set: my bond is forfeit else.
Where will you have it paid?
Faith, I am a stranger
Here in the country: Know you Canon Hugh,
The Vicar of Pancrace?
Yes, we who not him?
I will make him my Attorney to receive it,
And give you a discharge.
Whom shall I send for it?
Why, if you please, send Metaphore my Clarke.
And Turfe, I much commend thy willingness;
It is argument of thy integrity.
But my integrity shall be my self still:
Good Mr. Metaphore, give my wife this key;
And do but whisper it into her hand:
(She knows it well enough ) bid her, by that
Deliver you the two sealed bags of silver,
That lie in the corner of the cupboard, stands
At my bedside, they are fifty pound apiece;
And bring them to your Master.
If I prove not
As just a Carrier as my friend Tom Long was,
Then call me his curtal, change my name of Miles,
To Gutle's, Wile's, Piles, Bile's, or the foulest name
You can devise, to crambe with, for ale.
Come hither Miles, bring by that token, too,
Fair Awdrey; say her father sent for her:
Say Clay is found, and waits at Pancrace Church,
Where I attend to marry them in haste.
For (by this means) Miles I may say it to thee,
Thy Master must to Awdrey married be.
But not a word but mum: go get thee gone;
Be wary of thy charge, and keep it close.
O super-dainty Canon! Vicar inconey,
Make no delay, Miles but away.
And bring the wench, and money.
Now Sir, I see you meant but honestly;
And, but that business calls me hence away,
I would not leave you, till the sun were lower.
But Mr. Justice, one word, Sir, with you.
By the same token, is your Mistress sent for
By Metaphore your Clarke, as from her Father.
Who when she comes, I will marry her to you,
Unwitting to this Turfe, who shall attend
Me at the parsonage. This was my plot:
Which I must now make good; turn Canon,
In my square cap. I humbly take my leave.
Adieu, good Captain. Trust me, neighbour Turfe,
He seems to be a sober Gentleman:
But this distress hath somewhat stirred his patience.
And men, you know, in such extremities,
Apt not themselves to points of courtesy;
I am glad you have made this end.
You stood my friend:
I thank your Justice-worship; pray you be
Present anon, at tendering of the money,
And see me have a discharge: For I have no craft
In your Law quiblins.
I will secure you, neighbour.
Indeed, there is a woundy luck in names, Sirs,
And a maine mystery, if a man knew where
To find it. My God-sires name, I will tell you,
Was In-and-in Shittle, and a Weaver he was,
And it did fit his craft: for so his Shittle
Went in, and in, still: this way, and then that
way.
And he named me, In-and-in Medlay: which serves
A Joiners craft, because that
we do lay
Things in and in, in our work. But, I am truly
Architectonicus professor, rather:
That is (as one would say) an Architect.
As I am a Farrier, and a Visicarie:
Horse-smith of Hamsted, and the whole Town Leach --.
Yes, you have done woundy cures, Gossip Clench.
If I can see the stale once, through a Vrine-hole,
I will give a shrewd guess, be it man, or beast.
I cured an Ale-wife once, that had the staggers
Worse than five horses, without rowelling.
My Godfather was a Rabian, or a Jew,
(You can tell D'oge!) They called him Doctor Rasi.
One Rasis was a great Arabic Doctor.
He was Kind Harry's Doctor, and my Godfather.
Mine was a merry Greek, To-Pan, of Twyford:
A jovial Tinker, and a stopper of holes,
Who left me metal-man of Belsise, his heir.
But what was your D'Oge?
Faith, I cannot tell
If mine were christened, or no. But, sure he had
A Christian name, that he left me, Diogenes.
A mighty learned man, but pestilence poor.
For, he had no house, save an old Tub, to dwell in,
(I find that in records) and still he turned it
In the winds teeth, as it blew on his back-side,
And there they would lie routing one at other,
A week, sometimes.
Thence came A Tale of a Tub;
And the first Tale of a Tub, old Diogenes Tub.
That was afore Sir Peter Tub, or his Lady.
Aye, or the Squire their son, Tripoli Tub.
The Squire is a fine Gentleman!
He is more:
A Gentleman and a half; almost a Knight;
Within six inches: That is his true measure.
Sure, you can gage him.
To a streak, or less:
I know his diameters, and circumference:
A Knight is six diameters; and a Squire
Is five, and somewhat more: I know it by compass,
And scale of man. I have upon my rule here,
The just proportions of a Knight, a Squire;
With a tame Justice, or an Officer, rampant,
Upon the bench, from the high Constable
Down to the Head-borough, or
Tithing-man;
Or meanest Minister of the peace, God save him.
Why, you can tell us by the Squire, Neighbour,
Whence he is called a Constable, and what-for.
No, that is a bookcases: Scriben can do that.
That is writing and reading, and records.
Two words,
Cyning and Staple, make a Constable:
As we would say, A hold, or stay for the King.
All Constab Whatever their names are; be they
Tony, or Roger.
And all are sworn, as fingers of one hand,
To hold together against the
breach of the peace;
The High Constable is the Thumb, as one would say,
The hold-fast of the rest.
Pray luck he speed
Well in the business, between Captain Thums,
And him.
I will warrant him for a groat:
I have his measures here in arithmetic.
How he should bear unself in all the lines
Of his place, and office: Let us seek him out.
Hilts, how dost thou like of this
our good days work?
As good even never
a whit, as never the better.
Shall we go to Pancridge, or to Kentish-Towne,
Hilts?
Let Kentish-Towne, or Pancridge come to us
again.
Faith Basket, our success hath been but bad,
And nothing prospers, that we undertake;
For we can neither meet with Clay, nor Awdrey,
The Canon Hugh, nor Turfe the Constable:
We are like men that wander in strange woods,
And loose ourselves in search
of them we seek.
This was because we rose on the wrong side:
But as I am now here, just in the mid-way,
I will set my sword on the pommel, and that line
The point vales to, we will take; whether it be
To Kentish-Towne, the Church, or home
again.
Stay, stay thy hand: here is Justice Brambles Clarke,
The unlucky Hare hath crossed us all this day.
I will stand aside whilst thou pumpest out of him
His business, Hilts; and how he is now employed.
Let me alone, I will use him in his kind.
O for a Pad-horse, Pack-horse, or a Post-horse,
To bear me on his neck, his back, or his croup!
I am as weary with running, as a mill-horse
That hath led the Mill once, twice, thrice about,
After the breath hath been out of his body.
I could get up upon a pannier a panel,
Or, to say truth, a very Pack-saddle,
Till all my honey were turned into gall;
And I could sit in the seat no longer,
O the legs of the lackey now, or a foot-man,
Who is the Surbater of a Clarke currant,
And the confounder of his treslesse dormant.
But who have we here, just in the nick?
I am neither nick, nor in the nick: therefore
You lie Sir Metaphor.
Lie? how?
Lie so Sir.
I lie not yet in my throat.
Thou liest on the ground.
Dost thou know me?
