Yes, I did know you too late.
What is my name then?
Basket.
Basket? what?
Basket, the Great --
The Great? what?
Lubber --
I should say Lover, of the Squire his Master.
Great is my patience, to forbear thee thus,
Thou Scrape-hill, Scoundrel, and thou scum of man;
Uncivil, orange-tawny-coated Clarke:
Thou camest but half a thing into the world,
And wast made up of patches, parings, shreds:
Thou, that when last thou wert put out of service,
Travellest to Hamsted Heath, on a Ash wednesday,
Where thou didst stand six weeks the Iack of Lent,
For boys to hurl, three throws a penny, at thee,
To make thee a purse: Seest thou this, bold bright blade?
This sword shall shred thee as small unto the grave,
As minced meat for a pie. I will set thee in earth
All save thy head, and thy right arm at liberty,
To keep thy hat off, while I question thee,
What? why? and whether thou wert going now
With a face, ready to break out with business?
And tell me truly, lest I dash it in pieces.
Then Basket put thy smiter up, and hear;
I dare not tell the truth to a drawn sword.
It is sheathed, stand up, speak without fear, or wit.
I know not what they mean; but Constable Turfe
Sends here his key; for monies in his cupboard
Which he must pay the Captain, that was robbed
This morning. Smell you nothing?
No, Not I;
Thy breeches yet are honest.
As my mouth.
Do you not smell a rat? I tell you truth.
I think all is knavery: For the Canon whispered
Me in the ear, when Turfe had given me his key,
By the same token to bring Mrs. Awdrey,
As sent for thither; and to say Iohn Clay
Is found, which is indeed to get the wench
Forth for my Master, who is to be married,
When she comes there: The Canon has his rules
Ready, and all there to dispatch the matter.
Now on my life, this is the Canon's plot!
Miles, I have heard all thy discourse to Basket.
Wilt thou be true, and I will reward thee well,
To make me happy, in my Mistress Awdrey?
Your worship shall dispose of Metaphore,
Through all his parts, even from the
sole of the head,
To the crown of the foot, to manage of your service.
Then do thy message to the Mistress Turfe,
Tell her thy token, bring the money hither,
And likewise take young Awdrey to thy charge:
Which done, here, Metaphore, we will attend,
And intercept thee. And for thy reward,
You two shall share the money; I the Maid:
If any take offence, I will make all good.
But shall I have half the money Sir, in faith?
I on my Squire-ship, shalt thou: and my land.
Then, if I make not, Sir, the cleanliest scuse
To get her hither, and be then as careful
To keep her for you, as it were for
Down on your knees, and pray
that honest Miles
May break his neck ere he get over two
stiles.
Make haste then: we will wait here thy return.
This luck unlooked for, hath revived my hopes,
Which were oppressed with a dark melancholy.
In happy time, we lingered on the way,
To meet these summons of a better sound,
Which are the essence of my souls content.
This heartless fellow; a shame to serving-men;
Stain of all liveries; what seal makes him do!
How sordid, wretched, and unworthy things;
Betray his Masters secrets, ope the closet
Of his devises, force the foolish Justice,
Make way for your Love, plotting of his
own:
Like him that digs a trap, to catch another,
And falls into it himself!
So would I have it.
And hope it will prove a jest to twit the Justice with.
But that this poor white-livered Rogue should do it?
And merely out of fear?
And hope of money, Hilts.
A valiant man will nibble at that bait.
Who, but a fool, will refuse money proffered?
And sent by so good chance. Pray heaven he speed.
If he come empty-headed, let him count
To go back empty-headed; I will not leave him
So much of brain in his pate, with pepper and vinegar,
To be served in for sauce, to a Calves head.
Thou servest him rightly, Hilts.
I will fear as much
With my hand, as I dare say now with my tongue;
But if you get the Lass from Dargison,
What will you do with her?
We will think of that
When once we have her in possession, Governor.
You see we trust you, Mr. Metaphore,
With Mrs. Awdrey: pray you use her well,
As a Gentle-woman should be used. For my part,
I do incline a little to the serving-man;
We have been of a coat -- I had one like yours:
Till it did play me such a sleeveless errand,
As I had nothing where to put mine arms in,
And then I threw it off. Pray you go before her,
Serving-man-like: and see that your nose drop not.
As for example; you shall see me: mark,
How I go before her. So do
you: sweet Miles,
She for her own part, is a woman
cares not
What man can do unto her, in the way
Of honesty, and good manners. So farewell
Fair Mrs. Awdrey: Farewell Mr. Miles.
I have brought you thus far, onward on your way:
I must go back now to make clean the rooms,
Where my good Lady has been. Pray you commend me
To Bridegroom Clay; and bid him bear up stiff.
Thank you good Hanniball Puppy; I shall fit
The leg of your commands, with the straight buskins
Of dispatch presently.
Farewell fine Metaphore.
Come gentle Mistress, will you please to walk?
I love not to be led: I would go alone.
Let not the mouse of my good meaning, Lady,
Be snapped up in the trap of your suspicion,
To loose the tail there, either of her truth,
Or swallowed by the Cat of misconstruction.
You are too finical for me; speak plain Sir.
Welcome again my Awdrey: welcome
Love:
You shall with me; in faith deny me not.
I cannot brook the second hazard Mistress.
Forbear Squire Tub, as mine own
mother says;
I am not for your mowing. You will be flown
Ere I be fledge.
Hast thou the money Miles?
Here are two bags, there is fifty pound in each.
Nay Awdrey, I possess you for this time:
Sirs; Take that coin between you, and divide it.
My pretty sweeting give me now the leave
To challenge love, and marriage at your hands.
Now, out upon you, are you not ashamed?
What will my Lady say? in faith I think
She was at our house: And I think she asked for you:
And I think she hit me in the teeth with you,
I thank her Ladyship, and I think she means
Not to go hence, till she has found you. How say you?
Was then my Lady Mother at your house?
Let us have a word aside.
Yes, twenty words.
It is strange, a motion, but I know not what,
Comes in my mind, to leave the way to Totten,
And turn to Kentish-Towne, again
my journey:
And see my son Pol-marten with his Awdrey:
Ere while we left her at her fathers house:
And hath he thence removed her in such haste!
What shall I do? shall I speak fair, or chide?
Madam, your worthy son, with duteous care,
Can govern his affections: Rather than
Break off their conference some other way,
Pretending ignorance of what you know.
And this all, fair Awdrey: I am thine.
Mine you were once, though scarcely now your own.
'Slid my Lady! my Lady!
Is this my Lady bright?
Madam, you took me now a little tardy.
At prayers, I think you were: what, so devout
Of late, that you will shrive you to all Confessors
You meet by chance? Come, go with me, good Squire,
And leave your linen: I have now a business,
And of importance, to impart unto you.
Madam, I pray you, spare me but an hour;
Please you to walk before, I follow you.
It must be now, my business lies this way.
Will not an hour hence, Madam, excuse me?
Squire, these excuses argue more your guilt.
You have some new device now, to project,
Which the poor Tile-man scarce will thank you for.
What? will you go?
I have taken a charge upon me,
To see this Maid conducted to her Father,
Who, with the Canon Hugh, stays her at Pancrace,
To see her married to the same Iohn Clay.
It is very well; but Squire take you no care.
I will send Pol-marten with her, for that office:
You shall along with me; it is decreed.
I have a little business, with a friend Madam.
That friend shall stay for you, or you for him.
Pol-marten; Take the Maiden to your care;
Commend me to her Father.
I will follow you.
Tut, tell not me of following.
I will but speak
A word.
No whispering: you forget yourself,
And made your love too palpable: A Squire?
And think so meanly? fall upon a Cow-shed?
You know my mind. Come, I will to Turfe's house,
And see for Dido, and our Valentine.
Pol-marten, look to your charge; I will look to
mine.

stage.l: They all go out but Pol-marten and Awdrey.

sp.l: I smile to think after so many proffers
This Maid hath had, she now should fall to me:
That I should have her in my custody:
It were but a mad trick to make the essay,
And jump a match with her immediately:
She is fair, and handsome: and she is rich enough:
Both time, and place minister fair occasion:
Have at it then: Fair Lady, can you love?
No Sir, what is that?
A toy, which women use.
If it be a toy, it is good to play withal.
We will not stand discoursing of the toy:
The way is short, please you to prove it Mistress?
If you do mean to stand so long upon it;
I pray you let me give it a short cut, Sir.
It is thus, fair Maid: Are you disposed to marry?
You are disposed to ask.
Are you to grant?
Nay, now I see you are disposed indeed.
I see the wench wants but a little wit;
And that defect her wealth may well supply:
In plain terms, tell me, Will you have me Awdrey?
In as plain terms, I tell you who would have me.
Iohn Clay would have me, but he hath too hard hands;
I like not him: besides, he is a thief.
And Justice Bramble, he would fain have catched me:
But the young Squire, he, rather than his life,
Would have me yet; and make me a Lady, he says,
And be my Knight; to do me true Knights service,
Before his Lady Mother. Can you make me
A Lady, would I have you?
I can give you
A silken Gown, and a rich Petticoat:
And a french Hood. All fools love to be brave:
I find her humour, and I will pursue it.

stage.l: Lady. D. Turfe. Squire Tub. Hilts. Puppy. Clay.

sp.l: And as I told thee, she was intercepted
By the Squire here, my son: and this bold Ruffian
His man, who safely would have carried her
Unto her Father; and the Canon Hugh;
But for more care of the security,
My Usher hath her now, in his grave charge.
Now on my faith, and holy-dom, we are
Beholden to your worship. She is a Girl,
A foolish girl, and soon may tempted be:
But if this day pass well once over
her head,
I will wish her trust to
herself. For I have been
A very mother to her, though I say it.
Madam, it is late, and Pancridge is in your way:
I think your Ladyship forgets
yourself.
Your mind runs much on Pancridge. Well, young Squire,
The black Ox never trod yet On your foot:
These idle Phantasies will forsake you one day.
Come Mrs. Turfe, will you go take a walk
Over the fields to Pancridge, to your husband?
Madam, I had been there an hour ago:
But that I waited on my man Ball Puppy.
What Ball I say? I think the idle slouch
Be fallen asleep in the barn, he stays so long.
Satin, in the name of velvet-satin, Dame!
The Devil! O the Devil is in the barn:
Help, help, a legion -- Spirit Legion,
Is in the barn! in every straw a Devil.
Why dost thou bawl so Puppy?
Speak, what ails thee?
My name is Ball Puppy, I have seen the Devil
Among the straw: O for a Cross! a Collop
Of Friar Bacon, or a conjuring stick
Of Doctor Faustus! Spirits are in the barn.
How! Spirits in the barn? Basket go see.
Sir, if you were my Master ten times over,
And Squire to boot; I know, and you shall pardon me:
Send me among Devils? I see you love
me not:
Hell be at their game: I will not trouble them.
Go see; I warrant thee there is no such matter.
If they were Giants, it were another matter.
But Devils! No, if I be torn in pieces,
What is your warrant worth? I will see the Fiend
Set fire on the barn, ere I come there.
Now all Saints bless us, and if he be there,
He is an ugly sprite, I warrant.
As ever
Held flesh-hook, Dame, or handled fire-fork rather:
They have put me in a sweet pickle, Dame:
But that my Lady-Valentine smells of musk,
I should be ashamed to press into this presence.
Basket, I pray thee see what is the miracle!
Come, go with me: I will lead. Why standest thou man?
Cocks precious Master, you are not mad indeed?
You will not go to hell before your time?
Why art thou thus afraid?
No, not afraid:
But by your leave, I will come no near the barn.
Puppy! wilt thou go with me?
How? go with you?
Whither, into the Barn? To whom, the Devil?
Or to do what there? to be torn
amongst them?
Stay for my Master, the High Constable,
Or In-and-in, the Head-borough; let them go,
Into the Barn with warrant; seize the Fiend;
And set him in the stocks for his ill rule:
It is not for me that am but flesh and blood,
To meddle with him. For I cannot, nor I would not.
I pray thee Tripoly, look, what is the matter?
That shall I Madam.
Heaven protect my Master.
I tremble every joint till he be back.
Now, now, even now they are tearing him in pieces.
Now are they tossing of his legs, and arms,
Like Loggets at a Pear-tree: I will to the hole,
Peep in, and look whether he lives or dies.
I would not be in my Masters coat for thousands.
Then pluck it off, and turn thyself
away.
O the Devil! the Devil! the Devil!
Where man? where?
Alas that ever we were born. So near too?
The Squire hath him in his hand, and leads him
Out by the Collar.
O this is Iohn Clay.
Iohn Clay at Pancrace, is there to be married.
This was the spirit revelled in the Barn.
The Devil he was: was this he was crawling
Among the Wheat-straw? Had it been the Barley,
I should have taken him for the Devil in drink;
The Spirit of the Bride-ale; But poor Iohn,
Tame Iohn of Clay, that sticks about the bung-hole --
If this be all your Devil, I would take
In hand to conjure him: But hell take me
If ever I come in a right Devils
walk,
If I can keep me out on it.
Well meant Hilts.
But how came Clay thus hid here in the straw,
When news was brought, to you all he was at Pancridge;
And you believed it?
Justice Brambles man
Told me so, Madam: And by that same token,
And other things, he had away my Daughter,
And two sealed bags of money.
Where is the Squire?
Is he gone hence?
He was here Madam, but now.
Is the Hue and Cry past by?
Aye, aye, Iohn Clay.
And am I out of danger to be hanged?
Hanged Iohn? yes sure; unless, as with the Proverb,
You mean to make the choice of your own
gallows.
Nay, then all is well, hearing your news Ball Puppy,
You have brought from Paddington, I even
stole home here,
And thought to hide me, in the Barn
ever since.
O wonderful! and news was brought us here,
You were at Pancridge, ready to be married.
No faith, I never was further than
the Barn.
Haste Puppy. Call forth Mistress Dido Wisp,
My Ladies Gentle-woman, to her Lady;
And call yourself forth, and a
couple of maids,
To wait upon me: we are all undone!
My Lady is undone! her fine young son,
The Squire is got away.
Haste, haste, good Valentine.
And you Iohn Clay; you are undone too! All!
My husband is undone, by a true key,
But a false token: And myself is
undone,
By parting with my Daughter, who will be married
To somebody, that she
should not, if we haste not.
I pray thee good Pol-marten, show thy diligence,
And faith in both: Get her, but so disguised,
The Canon may not know her, and leave me
To plot the rest: I will expect thee here.
You shall Squire. I will perform it with all care,
If all my Ladies Ward-robe will disguise her.
Come Mistress Awdrey.
Is the Squire gone?
He will meet us by and by, where he appointed:
You shall be brave anon, as none shall know you.
I wonder, where the Queens High Constable is!
I fear, they have made him away.
No sure, The Justice
Dare not consent to that. He will see him forth
coming.
He must, for we can all take corpulent oath,
We saw him go in there.
Aye, upon record!
The Clock dropped twelve at Maribone.
You are right, D'oge!
Set down to a minute, now it is
almost four.
Here comes Squire Tub.
And his Governor, Mr. Basket.
Hilts, do you know him, a valiant wise fellow!
As tall a man on his hands, as goes on feet.
Bless you Mass' Basket.
Thank you good D'oge.
who is that?
D'oge Scriben, the great Writer Sir of Chalcot.
And, who the rest?
The wisest heads of the hundred.
Medlay the Joiner, Head-borough of Islington.
Pan of Belsize, and Clench the Leach of Hamsted.
The High Constables Counsel, here of Finsbury.
Present me to them, Hilts, Squire Tub of Totten.
Wise men of Finsbury: make place for a Squire,
I bring to your acquaintance, Tub of Totten.
Squire Tub, my Master, loves all men of virtue.
And longs (as one would say) till he be one of you.
His worship is welcome to our company:
Would it were wiser for him.
here be some of us,
Are called the witty men, over a hundred.
And some a thousand, when the Muster day comes.
I long (as my man Hilts said, and my Governor)
To be adopt in your society.
Can any man make a Masque here in this company?
A Masque, what is that?
A mumming, or a show.
With vizards, and fine clothes.
A disguise, neighbour,
Is the true word: There stands the man, can do it Sir.
Medlay the Joiner, In-and-In of Islington,
The only man at a disguise in
Midlesex.
But who shall write it?
Scriben, the great Writer.
He will do it alone Sir, He will join with no man:
Though he be a Joiner, in design he calls it.
He must be sole Inventor: In-and-In.
Draws with no other in his project, he will tell you,
It cannot else be feasible, or conduce:
Those are his ruling words? Please you to hear him?
Yes Mr. In-and-In, I have heard of you;
I can do nothing, I.
He can do all Sir.
They will tell you so.
I would have a toy presented,
A Tale of a Tub, a story of myself
You can express a Tub.
If it conduce
To the design, whatever is
feasible:
I can express a Wash-house (If need be)
With a whole pedigree of Tubs.
No, one
Will be enough to note our name, and family:
Squire Tub of Totten, and to show my adventures
This very day. I would have it in Tubs-Hall,
At Totten-Court, my Lady Mothers house,
My house indeed, for I am heir to it.
If I might see the place, and have surveyed it,
I could say more: For all Invention, Sir,
Comes by degrees, and on the view of nature;
A world of things, concur to the design,
Which make it feasible, if Art conduce.
You say well, witty Mr. In-and-In.
How long have you studied Ingine?
Since I first
Joined, or did in-lay in wit, some forty year.
A pretty time! Basket, go you and wait
On Master In-and-In to Totten-Court,
And all the other wise Masters; show them the Hall:
And taste the language of the buttery to them;
Let them see all the Tubs about the house,
That can raise matter, till I come -- which shall be
Within an hour at least.
It will be glorious,
If In-and-In will undertake it, Sir:
He has a monstrous medlay wit of his own.
Spare for no cost, either in boards, or hoops,
To architect your Tub: Have you never
a Cooper
At London called Vitruvius? send for him;
Or old Iohn Haywood, call him to you, to help.
He scorns the motion, trust to him alone.

stage.l: Lady. Tub. D. Tur. Clay. Puppy. Wisp.

sp.l: O, here is the Squire! you slipped us finely son!
These manners to your Mother, will commend you;
But in another age, not this:
well Tripoly,
Your Father, good Sir Peter (rest his bones)
Would not have done this: where is my Usher Martin?
And your fair Mrs. Awdrey?
I not see them,
No creature, but the four wise Masters here,
Of Finsbury Hundred, came to cry their Constable,
Who they do say is lost.
My husband lost?
And my fond Daughter lost? I fear me too.
Where is your Gentleman, Madam? Poor Iohn Clay,
Thou hast lost thy Awdrey.
I have lost my wits,
My little wits, good Mother; I am distracted.
And I have lost my Mistress Dido Wisp,
Who frowns upon her Puppy, Hanniball.
Loss! loss on every side! a public loss!
Loss of my Master! loss of his Daughter! loss
Of Favour, Friends, my Mistress! loss of all!
What Cry is this?
My man speaks of some loss.
My Master is found: Good luck, if it be thy will,
Light on us all.
O husband, are you alive?
They said you were lost.
Where is Justice Brambles Clarke?
Had he the money that I sent for?
Yes,
Two hours ago; two fifty pounds in silver,
And Awdrey too.
Why Awdrey? Who sent for her?
You Master Turfe, the fellow said.
He lied.
I am cozened, robbed, undone: your man is a Thief,
And run away with my Daughter, Mr. Bramble,
And with my money.
Neighbour Turfe have patience,
I can assure you that your Daughter is safe,
But for the monies I know nothing of.
My money is my Daughter; and my Daughter
She is my money, Madam.
I do wonder
Your Ladyship comes to know anything
In these affairs.
Yes, Justice Bramble
I met the maiden in the fields by chance,
In the Squires company my son: How he
Lighted upon her, himself best can tell.
I intercepted her, as coming hither,
To her Father, who sent for her, by Miles
Metaphore,
Justice Preambles Clarke. And had your Ladyship
Not hindered it, I had paid fine Mr. Justice
For his young warrant, and new Pursuivant,
He served it by this morning.
Know you that Sir?
You told me, Squire, a quite other tale,
But I believed you not, which made me send
Awdrey another way, by my Pol-marten:
And take my journey back to Kentish-Towne,
Where we found Iohn-Clay hidden in the barn,
To scape the Hue and Cry; and here he is.
Iohn Clay again! nay, then -- set
Cock-a-hoop:
I have lost no Daughter, nor no money, Justice.
Iohn Clay shall pay. I will look to you now John.
Faith out it must, as good at night, as morning.
I am even as full as a Pipers bag with
joy,
Or a great Gun upon carnation day!
I could weep Lions tears to see you Iohn.
It is but two fifty pounds I have ventured for you:
But now I have you, you shall pay whole hundred.
Run from your Burroughs, son: faith
even be hanged.
If you once earth yourself, Iohn, in the barn,
I have no Daughter for you: Who did ferret him.
My Ladies son, the Squire here, fetched him out.
Puppy had put us all in such a fright,
We thought the Devil was in the barn; and
Durst venture of him.
I am now resolved,
Who shall have my Daughter.
Who?
He best deserves her.
Here comes the Vicar. Canon Hugh, we have found
Iohn Clay again! the matter is all
come round.
Is Metaphore returned yet?
All is turned
Here to confusion: we have lost our plot;
I fear my man is run away with the money,
And Clay is found, in whom old Turfe is sure
To save his stake.
What shall we do then Justice?
The Bride was met in the young Squires hands.
And what is become of her?
None here can tell.
Was not my Mothers man, Pol-marten, with you?
And a strange Gentlewoman in his company,
Of late here, Canon?
Yes, and I despatched them.
Despatched them! how do you mean?
Why married them.
As they desired; But now.
And do you know
What you have done, Sir Hugh?
No harm, I hope.
You have ended all the Quarrel. Awdrey is married.
Married! to whom?
My Daughter Awdrey married,
And she not know of it!
Nor her Father, or Mother!
Whom hath she married?
Your Pol-marten, Madam.
A Groom was never dreamt of.
Is he a man?
That he is Turfe, and a Gentleman, I have made him.
Nay, if he be a Gentleman, let her shift.
She was so brave, I knew her not, I swear;
And yet I married her by her own
name.
But she was so disguised, so Lady-like;
I think she did not know herself
the while!
I married them as a mere pair of strangers:
And they gave out themselves for such.
I wish them
Much joy, as they have given me hearts ease.
Then Madam, I will entreat you now remit
Your jealousy of me; and please to take
All this good company home with you, to supper:
We will have a merry night of it, and laugh.
A right good motion, Squire; which I yield to:
And thank them to accept it. Neighbour Turfe,
I will have you merry, and your wife: And you,
Sir Hugh, be pardoned this your happy error.
By Justice Preamble, your friend and patron.
If the young Squire can pardon it, I do.
Stay my dear Dido, and good Vicar Hugh,
We have a business with you: In short, this
If you dare knit another pair of strangers,
Dido of Carthage, and her Countryman,
Stout Hanniball stands to it. I have asked consent,
And she hath granted.
But saith Dido so?
From what Ball-Hanny hath said, I dare not go.
Come in then, I will dispatch you. A good supper
Would not be lost, good company, good discourse;
But above all where wit hath any source.
After the hoping of your pardon, Madam,
For many faults committed. Here my wife,
And I do stand, expecting your mild doom.
I wish thee joy Pol-marten; and thy wife:
As much, Mrs. Pol-marten. Thou hast tricked her
Up very fine, methinks.
For that I made
Bold with your Ladyships Wardrobe, but have trespassed
Within the limits of your leave -- I hope.
I give her what she wears. I know all women
Love to be fine. Thou hast deserved it of me:
I am extremely pleased with thy good fortune.
Welcome good Justice Preamble; and Turfe,
Look merrily on your Daughter: She has married
A Gentleman.
So methinks, I dare not touch her
She is so fine: yet I will say, God bless her.
And I too, my fine Daughter. I could love her
Now, twice as well, as if Clay had her.
Come, come, my Mother is pleased. I pardon all,
Pol-marten in, and wait upon my Lady.
Welcome good Guests: see supper be served in,
With all the plenty of the house, and worship.
I must confer with Mr. In-and-In,
About some alterations in my Masque;
Send Hilts out to me: Bid him bring the Council
Of Finsbury hither. I will have such a night
Shall make the name of Totten-Court immortal:
And be recorded to posterity.

stage.l: Tub. Medlay. Clench. Pan. Scriben. Hilts.

sp.l: O Mr. In-and-In, what have you done?
Surveyed the place Sir, and designed the ground,
Or stand still of the work: And this it is.
First, I have fixed in the earth, a Tub;
And an old Tub, like a saltpetre Tub,
Preluding by your Fathers name Sir Peeter,
And the antiquity of your house, and family,
Original from saltpetre.
Good in faith,
You have shown reading, and antiquity here, Sir.
I have a little knowledge in design,
Which I can vary Sir to Infinito.
Ad Infinitum Sir you mean.
I do.
I stand not on my Latin, I will invent,
But I must be alone then, joined with no man.
This we do call the Stand-still of our work.
Who are those we? you now joined to
I mean myself still, in the
plural number,
And out of this we raise our Tale of a Tub.
No, Mr. In-and-In, my Tale of a Tub.
By your leave, I am Tub, the Tale is of me,
And my adventures! I am Squire Tub,
Subjectum Fabulæ.
But I the Author.
The Workman Sir! the Artificer! I grant you.
So Skelton-Lawreat; was of Elinour Bumming:
but the subject of the Rout, and Tunning.
He has put you to it, Neighbour In-and-In.
Do not dispute with him, he still will win.
That pays for all.
Are you revised of that?
A man may have wit, and yet put off his hat.
Now, Sir this Tub, I will have capped with paper:
A fine oiled Lantern-paper, that we use.
Yes every Barber, every Cutler has it.
Which in it doth contain the light to the business.
And shall with the very vapour of the Candle,
Drive all the motions of our matter about:
As we present them. For example, first
The worshipful Lady Tub.
Right worshipful,
I pray you, I am worshipful myself.
Your Squire-ships Mother, passeth by (her Usher,
Mr Pol-marten bareheaded before her)
In her velvet Gown.
But how shall the Spectators?
As it might be, I, or Hilts know it is my Mother?
Or that Pol-marten there that walks before her.
O we do nothing, if we clear not that.
You have seen none of his works Sir?
All the postures
Of the trained bands of the Country.
All their colours.
And all their Captains.
All the Cries of the City:
And all the trades in their habits.
He has his whistle
Of command: Seat of authority!
And virge to interpret, tipped with silver, Sir
You know not him.
Well, I will leave all to him:
Give me the brief of your subject. Leave the whole
State of the thing to me.
Supper is ready, Sir.
My Lady calls for you.
I will send it you in writing.
Sir, I will render feasible, and facile,
What you expect.
Hilts, be it your care,
To see the Wise of Finsbury made welcome:
Let them want nothing.
Is old Rosin sent for?
He is come within.
Lord! what a world of business
The Squire dispatches!
He is a learned man:
I think there are but few of the Inns of Court,
Or the Inns of Chancery like him.
Care to fit him then.
Yonder is another wedding, Master Basket,
Brought in by Vicar Hugh.
what are they, Iack?
The High Constables Man, Ball Hanny; and Mrs. Wisps,
Our Ladies woman.
And are the Table merry?
There is a young Tile-maker makes all laugh;
He will not eat his meat, but cries at the board,
He shall be hanged.
He has lost his wench already:
As good be hanged.
Was she that is Pol-marten,
Our fellows Mistress, wench to that sneake-Iohn?
Aye faith, Black Iack, he should have been her Bridegroom:
But I must go to wait on my wise Masters.
Iack, you shall wait on me, and see the Mask anon:
I am half Lord Chamberlain, in my Masters absence.
Shall we have a Masque? Who makes it?
In-and-In.
The Maker of Islington: Come go with me
To the sage sentences of Finsbury.
Come, give us in the great Chair, for my Lady;
And set it there: and this for Justice Bramble.
This for the Squire my Master, on the right hand.
And this for the High Constable.
This his wife.
Then for the Bride, and Bridegroom, here Pol-marten.
And she Pol-marten, at my Ladies feet.
Right.
And beside them Mr. Hanniball Puppy.
And this she Puppy, Mrs. Wisp that was:
Here is all are in the note.
No. Mr. Vicar:
The petty Canon Hugh.
And Cast-by Clay:
There they are all.
Then cry a Hall, a Hall!
It is merry in Tottenham Hall, when beards wag all.
Come Father Rozin with your Fiddle now,
And two tall-toters: Flourish to the Masque.

stage.l: Lady Preamble before her, Tub. Turfe. D. Turfe, Pol-marten,
Awdrey. Puppy. Wisp. Hugh. Clay. All take
their Seats. Hilts waits on the by.

sp.l: Neighbours, all welcome: Now doth Totten-Hall
Show like a Court: and hence shall first be called so.
Your witty short confession Mr. Vicar,
Within hath been the Prologue, and hath opened
Much to my sons device, his Tale of a Tub.
Let my Masque show itself: And
In-and-In,
The Architect, appear: I hear the whistle.
Peace.
Thus rise I first, in my light linen breeches,
To run the meaning over in short speeches.
Here is a Tub; A Tub of Totten-Court:
An ancient Tub, hath called you to this sport:
His Father was a Knight, the rich Sir Peeter;
Who got his wealth by a Tub, and by saltpetre:
And left all to his Lady Tub; the mother
Of this bold Squire Tub, and to no other.
Now of this Tub, and his deeds, not done in ale,
Observe, and you shall see the very Tale.

stage.l: He draws the Curtain, and discovers the top of the Tub.

sp.l: Ha
Peace.
The first Motion.
Here Canon Hugh, first brings to Totten-Hall
The high Constables council, tells the Squire all;
Which, though discovered (give the Devil his due:)
The wise of Finsbury do still pursue.
Then with the Justice, doth he counterplot,
And his Clarke Metaphore, to cut that knot:
Whilst Lady Tub, in her sad velvet Gown,
Missing her son, doth seek him up and
With her Pol-marten bare before her.
Yes,
I have expressed it here in figure, and Mistress
Wisp her woman, holding up her train.
In the next page, report your second strain.
Ha
Peace.
The second Motion.
Here the high Constable, and Sages walk
To Church, the Dame, the Daughter, Bride-maids talk,
Of wedding business; till a fellow in comes,
Relates the robbery of one Captain Thum's:
Chargeth the Bridegroom with it: Troubles all,
And gets the Bride; who in the hands doth fall
Of the bold Squire, but thence soon is taken
By the sly Justice, and his Clarke profane
In shape of Pursuivant; which he not long
Holds, but betrays all with his trembling tongue:
As truth will break out, and show, etc.
O thou hast made him kneel there in a corner,
I see now: there is simple honour for you Hilts!
Did I not make him to confess all to you?
True; In-and-In hath done you right, you see.
Thy third I pray thee, witty In-and-In.
The Squire commends them. He doth like all well.
He cannot choose. This is gear made to sell.
Ha
peace.
The third Motion.
The careful Constable, here drooping comes,
In his deluded search, of Captain Thum's.
Puppy brings word, his Daughter is run away
With the tall Serving-man. He frights Groom Clay,
Out of his Wits. Returneth then the Squire,
Mocks all their pains, and gives Fame out a Liar:
For falsely charging Clay, when it was the plot,
Of subtle Bramble, who had Awdrey got,
Into his hand, by this winding device.
The Father makes a rescue in a trice:
And with his Daughter, like Saint George on foot,
Comes home triumphing, to his dear Heart root.
And tells the Lady Tub, whom he meets there,
Of her sons courtesies, the Bachelor.
Whose words had made them fall the Hue and Cry.
When Captain Thum is coming to ask him, why
He had so done? He cannot yield him cause:
But so he runs his neck into the Laws.
Ha'
peace.
The fourth Motion.
The Laws, who have a noose to crack his neck,
As Justice Bramble tells him, who doth peck
A hundredth pound out of his purse, that comes
Like his teeth from him, unto Captain Thum's.
Thum's is the Vicar in a false disguise:
And employs Metaphore, to fetch this prize.
Who tells the secret unto Basket-Hilts,
For fear of beating. This the Squire quilts
Within his Cap; and bids him but purloin
The wench for him: they two shall share the coin.
Which the sage Lady in her aforesaid Gown
Breaks off, returning unto Kentish-Towne,
To seek her Wisp; taking the Squire along,
Who finds Clay Iohn, as hidden in straw throng.
O, how am I beholden to the Inventor,
That would not, on record against me enter!
My slackness here, to enter in the barn,
Well In-and-In, I see thou canst discern!
On with your last, and come to a Conclusion.
Ha' Peace.
The fifth Motion.
The last is known, and needs but small infusion
Into your memories, by leaving in
These Figures as you sit. I, In-an-In,
Present you with the show: First of a Lady
Tub, and her son, of whom this Masque here, made I.
Then Bridegroom Pol, and Mistress Pol the Bride:
With the sub-couple, who sit them beside.
That only verse, I altered
for the better, euponia gratiam.
Then Justice Bramble, with Sir Hugh, the Canon:
And the Bride's Parents, which I will not stand on,
Or the lost Clay, with the recovered Giles:
Who thus unto his Master, him reconciles,
On the Squires word, to pay old Turfe his Club,
And so doth end our Tale, here, of a Tub.
The end.
This Tale of me, the Tub of Totten-Court,
A Poet, first invented for your sport.
Wherein the fortune of most empty Tubs
Rolling in love, are shown; and with that rubs,
We are commonly encountered: When the wit
Of the whole Hundred so opposeth it.
Our petty Canon's forked plot in chief,
Sly Justice arts, with the High Constables Brief,
And brag Commands; my Lady Mothers care;
And her Pol-martens fortune; with the rare
Fate of poor Iohn, thus tumbled in the Cask;
Got In-and-In, to give it you in a Masque:
That you be pleased, who come to see a Play,
With those that hear, and mark not what we say.
Wherein the Poets fortune is, I fear,
Still to be early up, but never the near.
